item.title: About
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: The goal of this blog is to support statistics teachers and share some statistics love Contributors Anna-Marie Fergusson (Martin) teaches introductory-level statistics at the University of Auckland. Before joining theDepartment of Statisticsat the start of 2015, she was Head of Department (Mathematics and Statistics) at Avondale College. Anna's been teaching statistics for over 14 years and enjoys facilitating workshops to support professional development of statistics teachers. Follow @annafergussonnz Want to contribute to this blog? Want to give feedback? Then just send a message through the form below with your details and/or comments. item.title: Need data?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
Stuck for ideas for a good context for an investigation and/or need to get data? Here are some datato inspire an awesome statistical investigation, grouped by type of data.
Data cards Existing population data Existing sample data
Existing experiment data Time series data Creating data through sampling
Creating data through experiment Data for probability modelling Data for predictive modelling
If you would like to contribute - either with ideas of your own or other ideas you've found - then use the contact form on the About page to let me know :-)

item.title: Jordan Nelson - 2017-08-20 06:09:09
item.content:encoded:
Hi Anna-Marie,
I was a participant in your JSM - MWM presentation. I thought it was awesome! Thank you for coming so far to join us.
I currently teach high school statistics, and am going on my third year. Your blog has been such a great resource - I don't know how I never knew data cards existed!
I really enjoyed the facebook social media survey and graph sort. you gave out and the copies are great. I was just wondering if you had a digital copy I could use? I would really like to do this activity with my students.
Again, thank you so much for the presentation and all of the information. I hope our paths cross again in the future!

item.title: twentyseventeen
item.dc:creator: anna

item.title: Stats challenge for maths week - predictive text :-)
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This post discusses teaching ideas for the "predictive text challenge" that I've set up to support maths week 2015. Can your students predict the text readability score for any word? So its "maths week" here in New Zealand next week, and I had this idea yesterday that it would be cool to set up an on-line statistics challengefor students to attempt during the week. After some way more complicated ideas based on investigations I've done before with books (I'll do a post about those activities later), I decided a much "simpler" challenge would involve single words. You can check it out here:http://mathstatic.co.nz/predictive-text-challenge The basic ideas are:
  • Some words are easier/harder to read than others
  • The readability score used for this challenge was made up by me (there are others out there)
  • The score classifies words as "low", "medium" and "high" in terms of difficulty to read
  • The score I've devised uses various properties of each word, including its colour (black or red) and its font (normal or italics) to assign one of these scores - although students can just investigate a model for the word only without worrying about colour or font
How do students investigate the problem and form a model? Get students to try entering words and observing the readability scores for each word. After trying out different lengths words, they should be able to get an idea that the readability score might be something to do with the length of the word. Encourage students to record data by writing down the word, and then recording the readability score alongside this. Depending on what your students are using (pen and paper vs device), they could use a spreadsheet function like len() to count the letters of the word or just count them manually. I've designed the readability score so that there is a complex interaction of factors and it's not intended that students will be able to predict the readability score with 100% accuracy for any word. So there will be variation with the number of letters in each word for words with the same readability score. If students are not seeing this they probably have not tried out enough different words. Encourage your students to use graphs like dot plots to see if the can get a basic model for the readability score based on the number of letters of the word. Hint: The data above (20 words pulled from a random word generator website) suggest words 4 letters or lower will be scored as "low", 5 - 9 letters "medium" and 10 letters or above " high". This might be a good starting point for developing a model, but with only one word with 9 letters and only one word with 10 letters, are you really convinced? Some length words will need to be specifically used (quota sampling!)due to the natural distribution of word length in the English language and you should get students to draw graphs of the just the number of letters in the words they have checked to visualise and describe the distribution. Studentscould collaborate on collecting data by using something like a Google spreadsheet as with more data they will be able to get a better sense for what else is being taken into account to get the readability score.If they are stuck for words, there are random word generators out there on the world wide web for inspiration :-) Encourage your students to think about what else makes words easier or harder to read. I've designed the readability score so students are motivated to create new measures that may be a mix of qualitative and quantitative - putting them in the role of "data detective" (see the PPDAC poster on censusatschool.org.nz). In particular, looking at words with the same number of letters that are given different readability scores - get students to discuss what makes them different, and then get them to test out their rules. From this, its really up to your students (and you) how much further to take the modelling process. They could investigate what happens when you change the colour (this is easier than if you change the font, but they could do this too if they are up for the challenge). This is easier if you use software like iNZightwhich also has an on-line application called iNZight lite. This allows students to drag/add on third or fourth variables to their graphs to separate the data into related groups and explore relationships. I wouldn't make a big deal about formal notation for the model(s) - I think writing down some "rules" for how to take a word and predict its readability score is sufficient or actually even better drawing a diagram or picture (or even a tree). The main "takeaway" from the challenge hopefully is that there is more than one "thing" that the readability score is being based on. I'd be impressed if any student could "crack the code" that I've used to determined the readability score for each word but let me know if your students want to know how close they were :-) How will the challenge run? Monday to Tuesday Students test their own words through the on-line text analyser, record data from these tests, and try to develop a way to predict the readability score. They should make some notes/diagrams for their model and use these to predict readability scores for the first set of reserved words. Wednesday to Thursday Students have access to check the first set of reserved words. They enter the readability score they would predict for each reserved word, and see how this compares to the actual readability score. This should help them refine their prediction model. Friday Students have access to check the second set of reserved words. They enter the readability score they would predict for each reserved word, and see how this compares to the actual readability score. They should only do this once (i.e. this should be their final evaluation of the model). Keen to give it a go? Here's the place to send students:http://mathstatic.co.nz/predictive-text-challenge Please let me know if there are any issues in the comments below :-) NOTE: The challenge is over but I have left the page up in case you still want to try it out. Want to watch a cool visualisation for this kind of modelling? http://www.r2d3.us/visual-intro-to-machine-learning-part-1/

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Stats challenge for maths week - predictive text :-) ~ #statisticsisawesome

item.title: Tools
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
Modelling tool A tool to perform an informal test for goodness of fit, using simulation-based inference. Read more about the modelling tool here  
  BYOP (Bring your own population) sampling tool A simple tool that sets up a sampling interface based on a publicly hosted CSV file. Check out the blog post about why this tool was developed. Check out the BYOP sampling tool here.  
Random redirect tool Need torandomise which one of two links you send someone to? Check out the blog post about how to use this tool as part of an online experiment. Check out the random redirect tool here.  
Report comment writing tool A handy report comment writing tool that suggests comments as you write. Check out the blog post about the tool here. Check out the report comment writing tool here.  
Teacher gender prediction tool A little prediction tool that aims to predict your gender based on some questions about you as a teacher. Check out the blog post about the tool here. Or just get in and try out the teacher gender prediction tool now!

item.title: Privacy policy
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: Data collected through Google Analytics teaching.statistics-is-awesome.org uses www.google.com/analytics to collect visitor data and analyse traffic on our site. This information helps us understand who is visiting our site. When you visit our site, the pages that you look at, and a short text file called a cookie, are downloaded to your computer. A cookie is used to store small amounts of information. This information is collected for traffic analysis only. The cookie does not contain personal details. Depending on the browser that you use, you can set your preferences to block/refuse cookies, and/or notify you before they are placed. More information about how Google analytics works can be found here. All of our activity falls within the bounds of the Google Analytics Terms of Service. Data collected through teaching.statistics-is-awesome.orgonline tools or applications Data generated from using the online tools or applications provided on teaching.statistics-is-awesome.org may be recorded on our servers. For each online tool or application that collects data, there will be clear explanation of what information is being recorded. If you do not want to have your data recorded, then you can choose not to use the online tool or application. Public sharing of data Occasionally, we share data associated with this site to the public (because statistics is awesome!) No personally identifying data is included in this type of reporting. If you have any concerns about the data we share with the public, then please contact us.

item.title: What stories does your power data tell about you?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This post is about being aware what data we are creating and sharing we others. Smart meters and power data Last week Iwent about accessing our more recent power data to update a time series data set I used a couple of years ago based on our monthly power bills. It was then thatI noticed a feature for exporting data from my online electricity account: the ability to download our electricity data by each half hour period each day. I downloaded all the possible dates I could and ended up with nearly 25 000 rows of data (a year and a half's worth). I explored the data for a while, and was really intrigued by what I could tell from the data about our lives. I discussed what I had found withmy fiance who knowingly nodded and recalled that when smart meters where introduced for measuring power usage there was quite a bit of public reaction. A quick search later, and I found several articles, includingthis articlefrom Stuff published at the start of this year. Here are a couple of extracts from the article.....
The Office of the Privacy Commissioner yesterday fired a warning shot at power companies over the huge amounts of private details that smart meters collect every day. In a memo, the office said such meters, which are now installed in more than a million New Zealand homes and businesses, could take electricity readings detailed enough to determine whether customers were using high-energy appliances, such as ovens or heaters, and when they had left the house. But power companies said it was not possible to gather that level of detail, and all private electricity information was stored securely.
And.....
Smart meters have been introduced in New Zealand over the past few years and now read the electricity from about 1.2 million homes and businesses, outnumbering the old meters. By reading electricity use twice an hour, the theory is that customers should be billed only for the power they use, and energy companies are able to use the stream of almost real-time information to plan supply more accurately. Electricity and Gas Complaints Commissioner Judi Jones said smart meters did give power companies a lot of personal information that could be used to work out household routines, such as when customers went to bed or when they left the house. "Over the course of the day, you can say what is being used or not. You can see when the kids come home and turn on the television."
  The key question is - should you be worried about this? Well, chances are the power company actually has personal information about you like your date of birth, bank account number or credit card information, credit history (since if you are paying on account there would have been a credit check). But perhaps part of the issue is a lack of awareness of the kind of things the data can be used to tell you, and whether having this historic data would help them do their job better. So......... I will use our data to show you a little bit more about my household. Resources to discuss (from Googleing investigations time series power electricity) http://nzmaths.co.nz/taxonomy/term/21 http://nzmaths.co.nz/resource/using-electricity http://www.schoolgen.co.nz/pdf/SE_L3-4_FS_Graphing.solar.data.pdf http://www.branz.co.nz/cms_show_download.php?id=b1ab61dd06f50e83e6a184b29b68a989472502ed

item.title: resource deluge
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
The thing that I am trying to get my head around is how best to provide/share resources for teaching statistics. Thoughts? Ideas? I made a start with my own blog but it takes me ages to develop anything because I don't think it is as simple or effective just to share all the resources I created during my time teaching. My experiences with leading a huge department of teachers also informs me that all the great resources in the world won't make a difference if you don't have a clear idea of what needs to be taught (lesson planning and content knowledge) and what teaching strategies are effective for learning statistics (student activities and formative assessment).
I don't think "resource deluge" is the answer, which would be even more increased with open sharing on census at school and the pond, and other social networks like Facebook groups or google drive folders.
It's like delivering a whole lot of groceries to a family that is really hungry or not that confident cooking and expecting them to make great dinners without any help. The quality of the groceries will vary greatly (e.g. milk that has gone off compared to very expensive wine) and the quantity of different types of groceries may be really unbalanced (e.g. lots of carbs but hardly any meat). If the family is really hungry, they will just use whatever you give them straight away without really thinking about the best way to use the groceries. If they are not that confident with cooking, they will just fall back on making the meals they already know how to make - even if you give them the most amazing piece of salmon steak. Cooking a great dinner is a mix of creating something edible but also something that tastes good. Anyway, I'm sure you get my point..... although I could go way further with that analogy :-) My food bag is an interesting idea related to this analogy: http://www.myfoodbag.co.nz/how-it-works
I think part of the issue is the resources shared are not always planned to be shared as guiding documents - they are likely the artefacts of a workshop presentation and so don't necessarily capture the important stuff about the teaching strategies etc. At the same time, you can't expect teachers to think about their resources when they have already given up time for free to do the workshop in the first place.
I was talking with Pip last week and we both agreed that one of the best resources is not the actual resource itself but the conversations with and mentoring from effective statistics teachers about teaching statistics.

item.title: How do we deal with outliers?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This post provides the notes for an Ignite presentation I ran at the Christchurch Mathematical Association (CMA) 2015 Statistics Day on dealing with outliers. If you are not familiar with an Ignite presentation, it is 20 slides that auto-advance every 15 seconds for a total presentation of five minutes! So this summary won't really capture the experience :-)
Cartoon from CAUSEweb.org created by J.B. Landers My goal for this presentation is to try to tackle the tricky issue of how we can help students to deal with outliers in meaningful and appropriate ways. All in five minutes!
  I have some first hand experiences of outliers. My parents had 30 year age difference and I am one of eleven children.
  But here is a more familiar and frustrating example of an outlier (a reaction time of over four minutes!) which makes this display very unhelpful. So why not just delete?
We want students to investigate unusual values. Like this time of over 8 hours to run the Auckland half marathon (21 km) earlier this month.
  With over 5000 times, deleting this value doesn't actually affect the summary statistics dramatically. But........
  Does this value even make sense? The race started at 6:50am and the race information says times won't be recorded after 1pm.
  So it's not possible for this time to be over 8 hours. An email to the organisers confirms this is a mistake and the real time was about 1.5 hours.
  This running example shows these steps being followed but why do students still not get it?
  What are students thinking when they look at data and making decisions about outliers? I suspect teachers and students see different things!
  We look at experimental data like this and don't seen anything interesting happening because there isn't much data to begin with.
  Students look at the same data and see groupings and complex shapes.
  We look at a scatter plot like this one and focus more on the amount of scatter and can imagine the data WITHOUT the line.
  Students look at the same plot and get excited about the "outliers" and how the model would be better if they delete them. They can't unsee the line.
  We look at this randomisation test output and think how inappropriate that is for at least two reasons!
  Students look at the same randomisation test output and are ecstatic that they got a "significant" result. It's all about the p value!
  We can't deal with outliers in isolation from the distributional features that we expect to see (or not see) when considering sources of variation.
  We also need to teach the statistical reasons and understandings for why we care about outliers in the first place.
For example the difficulty of distributional feature spotting with small amounts of data (we expect to see gaps) but also the greater the impact of extreme values on many measures.
  Or how some types of outliers (not all!) can affect the model estimates when using linear regression.
  Teaching students to dealing with outliers takes time. 10 years ago I was an outlier within my family as the only child to go to University and get a degree, but there are now three of us :-)

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: How do we deal with outliers? #statisticsisawesome #statsed

item.title: Time to re-think resources?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: I wanted to talk about resources as part of a presentation I did at the end of last year. But I ran out of time! So instead I will try to write up what I wanted to say here on the blog. Resources, resources, resources........ We all want them, we all need them, we all wish that were more resources, morewell designed resources, morefree resources. Sure we hoard them-we have a tendency to store all the resources we come across (or seek out) like canned food just in case there is a natural disaster. Yeah, some of those cans have a thick layer of dust accumulating on them, but what if there came a day when we might need them??? I'd like to say that with digital resources the dust issue is not really a problem anymore, but there must be an electronic version of dust for the files that have not been access for three or more years, or the files that are deep within subfolders of subfolders of folders called things like "resources for teaching statistics" and other useful markers. I'd like to think with cloud storage and other collaboration tools that there would be less duplicates of resources and more single files where changes are tracked and easily reversed, rather than the dreaded v1, v2, v3 files, but I'm not sure our mindset has changed. We want to have copies of stuff for ourselves, stored on our drives, just in case..........just in case...... I'd love to believe that our workload issues with teaching could be alleviated byall teachers getting on boardwith sharing platforms like The Pond or free sites or software to share their resources. But I only have to look at the state of my many many many many resources accumulated over 13 years of teaching to know that I would be doing more harm than good if I just dumped all of these resources somewhere for other teachers to have access to. Why? Because I think resources are like clothes. And resource sharing is like recycling clothes. Just because you can recycle your clothes doesn't mean that anyone else should (or wants) to wear them. And if you want to help someone dress better, giving them all your favourite clothes (and not so favourite clothes) isn't necessarily going to mean they know how to select from them to create good outfits. I've also held on to some shockers - items that really should not see the light of day anymore. So I should not be recycling those clothes as it would not be a positive thing for the community - I now realise the error of my ways, and should either re-design that piece of clothing before recycling or just throw it out! (OK - I think you get my point - I could take this metaphor very very far .....). Just think about your local op shop. We have quite a fancy one near our house. The clothes used on the display mannequins make those dolls look amazing, stylish and definitely sell the whole idea of buying clothes from the shop. But once inside, you need to sort through all the stuff that is on offer and select the items that could look good on you and when combined create an equally stylish outfit. And that takes skill (of which I do not have by the way!). Not everything in the op shop is great - and some people are better and sorting out the difference between the good and the bad. It's not about quantity, it's about quality. I know one of the reasons people don't share things is because they don't think they are good enough to share. I say, fair enough. You should believe your resource is great if you want to share it with others. But I know that I don't share things as freely as perhaps others would like for a different reason. Because I don't think the resource itself is the answer to helping improve teaching of statistics. Just like teaching without assessment is not teaching (it is like speaking without listening), sharing without conversation is not sharing. So, I'm thinking about new teachers, or teachers new to teaching statistics, (and actually even "experienced" teachers who need help with updating their pedagogy and teaching practice), and what should be our approach to using and sharing resources in a way that is (a) effective (b) positive and (c) sustainable.If you are new to teaching, and someone gave you a folder of resources, or a collection of webpages, how useful would that be for you to plan an effective lesson, particularly for a topic that you have not taught before? Put yourself into the position of someone who has no "dress sense" and really think about what strategies would be good to help this person "dress for success"? If you have not yet developed your personal philosophy on teaching or knowledge of who are "experts" to trust in terms of resources, how do you even know what to "buy"? So to continue this clothes analogy further, I propose we consider a capsule wardrobe approach to resources. A minimalist approach to simplify our lives and hopefully increase our enjoyment of lesson planning and teaching. Like I described above, I think we need to consider how we use resources ourselves first before we share with others. If we are not organised. I also would like to put some responsibility on various government organisations for providing some of these resources - particularly the "holeproof" underwear! You need a solid understanding of what you are teaching. The facts, the concepts, the knowledge, the misunderstandings. This resource should be clear, concise, undisputable, and be part of a common body of knowledge for teachers. This shouldn't vary from school to school, teacher to teacher. The few key items that form the basis of your wardrobe should be a sequence of lessons that demonstrates good teaching practice, that develop key understandings. You only need a couple of these, and the point is that they are good examples of good lessons that if followed would have a high rate of success. They could also be smaller items/activities, that when used as part of a lesson or combined with others will work well. But they are at the basic level they are solid, reliable, well constructed resources from expert teachers. Once you have gained confidence with the few key items that you can mix and match to make lessons, you're ready to see some interesting stuff to elevate your lesson to the next level of awesomeness. The thing is, are you wearing underwear? Do you have the basics? Where are you getting guidance from? Are you reflecting on your lessons?           am not against sharing resources but I a Somewhere in all of this are really good resources butI think it could make sense toapproach resources like a capsule wardrobe. In a nutshell, the concept is quality over quantity and less is more. If you have a few key pieces of clothes that you know look good and are ones that you can mix and match to makebasicoutfits, this can give you more time and confidence to focus on other things to make your outfit more exciting or appealing.If you are like me and know very little about what makes for good fashion, how do know what the key items for your capsule wardrobe should be? Well, you need to find a good example of a capsule wardrobe that you can copy (if you are actually interested in capsule wardrobes, I'd suggest reading this). So, what I'd like to see more of is the sharing of good well-designed lessons I much prefer the idea of enabling other teachers to be able to create their own resources and in doing so build confidence and understanding of what makes for good statistics teaching. This starts with getting the basics right and then building on this solid foundation. The bigger idea I have around this approach to resources is shown in the diagram below. The underwear without holesrepresents sound curriculum knowledge of what you need to teach, a few items that form the basis of the wardrobeis what this post will focus on and represents knowledge of the design of effective learning activities and having good structures and pedagogy to use that promote statistical thinking, a few interesting pieces to help you dress more stylishly represents ideas, contexts, data sets, resources that you need to keep updating to keep your learning activities fresh and fun,a few good magazines to learn more from and to inform future purchases is what this post will also focus on and represents knowing where to look to get good advice or professional development for your teaching and finallya giant mirror to help you reflect on your dressingrepresents the need to regularly review the resources you are using (and so your teaching/learning activities) through self critique and the critique of others (including your students).
item.category: 10 ways to embrace the awesomeness that is our statistics curriculum

item.title: Time to get time seri-ous?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: A good teaching friend of mine asked me a little while back to do a post about time series. I have kind of avoided doing any posts that are specifically about a particular standard or assessment, but unfortunatelythere is a lot of stuffout there in cyberland about teaching time series (workbooks, videos, shared student work, websites etc.) that really gets me asking "Seriously?"thatI think maybe it is worth breaking my rules.So here are my suggestions for 10 ways to get serious about teaching time series.... 1.Repeat after me......time series modelling, time series modelling Yep, the theme of Level 8 of the New Zealand Curriculum from my perspective is modelling. 1a. Don't focus on the maths or technology - focus on the modelling 2. Check out the new re-organisation of Census At School NZ 3. Read the time series document from the national facilitators Or if you've already read it, hereis a summary of the best bits in my opinion and with my own interpretation. First, be careful about the data you use for assessment. Don't give students time series data for assessment that can only be modelled multiplicatively. This is not fair for your students. Don't tell me they get multiplicative models. They don't. Yep, show them crazy data all you want in teaching to make the point that some data can not be modelled well because of its features, but don't limit their chances to show understanding of time series modelling by not checking out the data you want to use first. Use the data. Write up your own reports. Check that there is enough to talk about. 4. Watch Data to Insight videos 5. Use real data that is additive in nature -- here are some examples 6. Be wary of multiplicative models and people telling you to teach them OK, so this is definitely a rant time. Here is the thing, additive models are easier to understand than multiplicative models. There is enough good stuff in the process of using an additive model for time series data for students to really get into to both introduce and extend key ideas. The need of alternative models, including multiplicative, should be just that - a need that can be explained clearly by the students about why an additive model is not doing a good job as a model. An argument that most time series data is multiplicative and so that is what we should be teaching is synonmonous with saying that most sampling methods are multi-stage and complex, so that is what we should be teaching. And there is definitely not a shortage of time series data which "behaves well" and which can be modelled using additive models. There is also a difference between crazy data which we should not be asking our students to model anyway! Let's get some perspective people. 7. If you must do multiplicative.... Then make sure you actually understand how the model works.Multiplicative models are not just about "when the seasonal effects increase/decrease over time" - they change up the modelling process conceptually and are harder to visualise. It comes down to the components of your model and how you want them to interact. 8. Treat this like the boardroom.... I used to this whole "Donald Trump" thing about how to avoid getting yourself fired in the board room because of who you present your findings from a time series investigation. Sometimes I think we need to 9. 10. Do tertiary-level study about time series models I would put this first on my list of suggestions, but I know that it could be the most frustrating one to read for busy teachers who are already working really hard to do the best for their students. IN terms of my own experiences, my undergraduate study was in operations research, so I had not done time series modelling or regression modelling to advanced levels. In my second year of teaching, I completed two papers extramurally (time series models and linear regression models) and I have been sorted ever since that in terms of having that required "horizon knowledge" that goes beyond what we teach students at high school level. This study allowed me to put things into perspective and sort out the big ideas from the silly ones. (1) Census at School teaching resources re-organisation Time series was the first area to get a re-design in terms of organisation of resources. If you haven't looked at this yet, head there now. My top picks are in the (2) National facilitators document on Time Series This was put together by Derek Smith and the rest of th and attempts to clarify some understandings around the achievement standard AS91580. Some really important stuff in there regards data to use for assessment, which is basically time series data that is not too crazy which leads me to.. (3) Infoshare on stats.govt.nz Head here NZ based time series. This stuff real and must be useful since it is collected. Figure.nz also presents much of the same data, and provide data sets which can be used. What you need is a way to make this accessible and meaningful to students.   Exploring features of time series data, quantifying these features in some way to build models, generalising these features to make forecasts... What is a model? This is actually a difficult question and there are a number of accepted answers within mathematics and statistics. But for this post about time series, I am going to go with this answer - a model is a mathematical equation that maps a certain value(s) for a defined variable(s) to another variable. In statistical models, we expect to see the model include a component for "random error", in an appreciation of the uncertainty of the variable being modelled (random variation). With time series models, our "explanatory" variable is time Additive vs multiplicative models For students to get their heads around multiplicative models, in my opinion they need to have firm clear confident understanding of additive models. Introducing multiplicative models should not be underestimated in terms of understanding. It's not just a case of stating that when seasonality appears to increase or decrease over time in absolute size, that we should go with a multiplicative model. This states the feature, but does not illuminate why multiplying a seasonal effect works better than using a fixed component entirely. It does in that we see why using a fixed average will be too low or too high for different like values of the series (e.g. the different januaries) but it doesn't necessarily explain why it would be better to multiply the trend, which itself could also be changing over this time...... to really get the relationship between trend and seasonality involves looking a lot of multiplicative modelling appropriate data to see what generally happens... with higher values of the series, there tends to be more variation..... (think Poisson). But also, an important feature of the data to allow for good multiplicative modelling is that the ratio of seasonal effects within the seasonal cycle (e.g. each year) remains similar no matter the actual values of the series

item.title: What's in a name?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: This post about NZ baby and children's names has been sitting in my drafts for about sevenmonths! Atthe start of each year, the Department of Internal Affairs (NZ) tends to issue a press release about the most popular baby names for the previous year. As a teacher I look at these "popular names" and feel like this list doesn't really quite capture the true story of the diversity of names our students have in New Zealand. Part of the reason it is lacking is because it is only the top 100 names (more about this later). We also get other articles in the paper or online about baby name trends, but often this data is from overseas from countries such as the U.S. or the U.K., sometimes Australia. Our country has it's own unique set/distribution of names, which is constantly changing as our country grows and develops its own identity. A good idea at the time :-) Last year I developedCensus at School stick people data cardsand deliberately chose to not label each stick person with a gender but to use a name instead. I thought it would be cool to get students to consider whether they could tell the gender by the stick person's name, and if not, if there was any way they could predict what gender the stick person was using the other information known about the stick person. Well, yeah, turns out it can be quite difficult. The names I used for the stick people data cards are real NZ names but   child's gender by name * NZ baby name popularity visualisation --> link to louise's stuff on census at school * link to CaS stick people data cards where there are no genders just names, andlink to updated version of the population csv file so genders are included * signal that something cool is on its way with the data cards Watch this space! Visually representing data through the use of technology such as graphing software is an exciting and essential part of teaching and learning statistics. Learning softwaresuch as iNZight lite(the online version of iNZight) takes the art of exploring data further than just producing graphs from a data set, and incorporates research-based features to support students to "get into the data faster" [to quote Chris Wild]. Some of these features involve automatically creating graphs based on the types of variables selected, the use of animation, colour and other visual graphical techniques, and the use of sound design principles to ensure consistency in how the user interacts with the software across the many different types of analysis possible. Thiscareful thinking about how to support students explore data meaningfully also needs to start off the computer, back when we first use hands-on activities and tools such as data cards. When we move from "hands on" methods to technology-based methods to create graphs, we can make assumptions that students make this transition easily.I know that I have been guilty of thinking that students understand plots like dot plots since to me they are simple representations - each dot is a person, and we just stack people/dots with the same value, in order from lowest to highest across the horizontal axis - done! But I (and many others e.g. ***********) think that graphicacy is an important area of statistics education that needs moreresearch and needs careful thinking. As one of my many side projects to my Master's research this year, I am working on something very cool to support the transition from data cards to online learning software. If you are a BYOD school then you will be interested.   Teacher post about the tool.... The tool visualises the names over time from 1954 to 2014 Allows for more detail Also, put your name in and see it;s popularity over time (for top 100 each year)   So, turns out January is a popular month for New Zealanders to search for "baby names" via Google ..... [sc name="google-trend"] ... or it might be that it's just the time when the Department of Internal Affairs puts out its media release regarding popular baby names... http://www.dia.govt.nz/press.nsf/d77da9b523f12931cc256ac5000d19b6/9c8ef876d23b0bf7cc257f310070e227!OpenDocument ... and newspapers create their own articles to match http://www.stuff.co.nz/life-style/parenting/baby/75607255/new-zealands-top-100-baby-names-for-2015 http://m.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=11570003 Last year I came across this article last year which had a visualisation for the 100 popular names The number of babies with the top 100 names has decreased from 1954 - back then around 70% of babies had one of the top 100 names.... in 2014 only about 35% of babies have one of the top 100 names. So this means that the popularity competition involves less babies due to a greater diversity of baby names :-) To see what I mean, select the girls, and then click on 1954 to sort the baby names in order of ranking. Christine is number one with 779 babies given this name. Now click on 2014 and Charlotte is the number one name with 255 babies given this name. Scroll down to the 100th baby Hayley with 39 babies but you see that others like Marie, Freya etc also had only 39 babies born with that name. Not big numbers :-) Louise's stuff https://drive.google.com/drive/u/1/folders/0BxSVTfVbi4l6cU1iYVRvN2ZpOEk (should be on census at school later)   http://www.nzherald.co.nz/lifestyle/news/article.cfm?c_id=6&objectid=11854900 Five thirty eight https://fivethirtyeight.com/features/how-to-tell-someones-age-when-all-you-know-is-her-name/   http://learning.statistics-is-awesome.org/babynames/

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: What's in a name? Exploring NZ baby and child names .... #statsed #teachingstatistics #statisticsisawesome

item.title: BYOP sampling
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This is an onlinesampling tool which allows you to bring your own population in the form of a csv file which is hosted publicly somewhere on the web.This tool currently runs through my old mathstatic.co.nz website. I've written more about why I developed it here. At some stage Ill move the tool onto this statistics-is-awesome.org website You can see the sampling tool in action herehttp://www.mathstatic.co.nz/sampler-new/UFNXFXDF(for this example I used the Auckland Marathon 2015 data).You can enter in the sample size you want (to a max of 30% of the size of the data set), and if you want, you can choose to only sample from certain groups within the population e.g. age division (Up to 34 vs 35 - 39). You can then copy and paste the sample generated to wherever you like, export the sample as a csv file, or jump straight into iNZight lite with the data.I've made the page deliberately plain, so it will be up to you to provide the information about the data being used and how to use the tool. The instructions for setting up the tool are below:

Step 1

Use a csv file already hosted publicly on a website Check that the link, when accessed, automatically starts the download of the csv file. Also check the csv file has the variable names as thefirst row and that the second row has data for each variable (no missing values in the second row) e.g. http://www.mathstatic.co.nz/nz_super_surf.csv[this data set is from Statistics NZ] OR Use your own data via Google drive* Create a Google spreadsheet with your data. The first row needs to be the variable names.The second row needs to have data for each variable (no missing values). Publish the sheet with the population data using File Publish to the web Under Link choose the sheet (probably Sheet1) and select Comma-separated values (.csv) [caption id="attachment_1686" align="alignnone" width="568"] The options to select in Google drive using File --> Publish to the web[/caption] After you click the blue Publish button you will get a link like this one (check that it ends with output=csv): https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/13OEIOgRukChp-D2XghnfGAt6i-AdzK9-5z7eyDDhvak/pub?gid=0&single=true&output=csv * You probably can use other cloud based drives, I just havent checked how they work. I know with Dropbox you have to change the "?dl=0" to "?dl=1" in the link to the csv file for it to work.
NOTE: The data in your Google spreadsheet will be published publicly, but students/others would need the crazy URL to access it, which students/others dont get to see. You can of course stop the publishing your data at any point and consequently thesampler URLwill not work. This tool does not copy your data or store it on our servers.

Step 2

Chuck this URL into the tool found here http://mathstatic.co.nz/sampler-new to get a sampler URL like this onehttp://www.mathstatic.co.nz/sampler-new/KOQKBVJH Share the sampler URL with your students. This will give students a plain interface and from this interface, students can sample from your population data set, and either show the sample on the screen (to copy and paste somewhere), download a csv file, or jump with the data into iNZight lite. [caption id="attachment_1679" align="alignnone" width="546"] A random sample of 5 females from the NZ super SURF[/caption]

Step 4

Let me know if there are any issues :-)
Head tohttp://mathstatic.co.nz/sampler-new to give it go :-) [caption id="attachment_1660" align="alignleft" width="967"] Set up the BYOP sampling URL[/caption]

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Sampler new

item.title: Random redirector
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This tool currently runs through my old mathstatic.co.nz website. At some stage I'll move it onto this statistics-is-awesome.org website :-) This tool is similar to the wide range of URL shorteners out there e.g. goo.gl, tiny.cc, bit.ly etc., except that the shortened URL will send you to one of two links at random. I couldn't find anything like this out there when I searched (but I may have been using the wrong search words!) which is why I set up this tool. [Edit:Scroll down to the bottom to learn how to set up your own random redirects using Google App Scripts] It is useful in particular for online experiments, where you want to send participants to one of two different pages (e.g. a Google survey) without them necessarily being aware of this randomisation process. To setup the URL, head tohttp://mathstatic.co.nz/autoand follow the instructions on the page. [caption id="attachment_1649" align="alignnone" width="894"] Set up the random redirect URL[/caption] Want to set up your own random redirects without using my tool? Awesome! Here is something you could do using Google App Scripts.
  1. Under Google Drive, create a new Google Apps Script (you might have to look under "More" after you click the "New" button).
  2. Give your project a name e.g.Randomredirect
  3. In theCode.gs tab, delete what is there and replace with this code.
  4. Replace the links to the Google formswith your own :-)
  5. Save the project then select "Deploy as web app" from the "Publish" menu. Under "Who has access to the app" select "Anyone, even anonymous".
You should then get a "Current web app URL:" that looks something like this:https://script.google.com/macros/s/AKfycbwu_Fv8gGGbzMCqot1e1-u8TereYJ9uJVfIMw02NxNUTj9WNII/exec You can then give people this URL (or use a URL shortener first to make it look nicer e.g.https://goo.gl/, or embed it in an existing webpage), and it willrandomly redirect them to one of the Google forms you've added to thecode.

item.title: You say strata I say nada ....
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
I've had a couple of queries of the last couple of days regarding the BYOP sampling tool. I'll update the information in the postHey! You've got to hide that population away, but you won't know I've done this if you've already read the post, so I am going to do an update/explanation here :-) Stratified sampling My quick-ish response to the request to be able to do stratified sampling with the BYOP samplingtoolisthatyou can do this by repeating the sampling process and combining the samples e.g. take one sample of 100 men only, then another sample of 50 women only, and then combine if you want the ratio of men and women in the sample to be 2 : 1.Also, if you just wanted to sample 100 women and 100 men, then again you could do this separately and then combine. However, I see no need for students to USEstratified sampling at any level for their investigations requiring sample to population inference. Now for the longer response......
The more interesting and difficult questions related to stratified sampling are: What do you use for your strata? and How many do you sample from each strata?
So whatdo you use for your strata? Imagine that the problem for your AS91264investigation was "Is the mediannumber of text messages sent by male senior studentsat our schoolgreater than the median number of text messages sent by female senior students at our school?" Considering that for AS91264 we don't require students to estimate a single population median (e.g. the median number of text messages sent per day for the senior students at our school), then using the two groups within variable being compared as the strata doesn't seem massively justified (e.g. using gender - male vs female - to stratify). That is, we are not seeking to improve our estimate for the population median by weighting our sample. The population data sets we provide studentsshould be suchthat a simple random sample gives"enough" data for each group to be compared. I suppose if you were super worried about not getting enough data for eachgroup, you could take two separate samples and combine, but then I would be worried about how much data you are using for your population data set. I'm still not sure it matters for a simple comparison of two independent groups whether thesample sizes for each group areproportional. I could see an advantage of using the groups within another variable as the strata (e.g. year level - Y12 vs Y13) ifit was known that Y13 students text more than Y12 students ...BUT ..... this contextual knowledge wouldn't come from looking at the whole population data set! Deciding on strata and sampling fractions shouldnot come from exploring the population data set before sampling (e.g. producing graphs for each combination of categorical and numerical variable). Students should not be counting how many casesthere are in each group from the population data set we want students to sample from. In saying all of this though, I have never taught students to actually DO this for their sampling (stratify using a third related variable), but rather have encouraged them to THINKabout the possible impact of a third variable on what they have found (there is more about this in this postNot so awesome interpretations). So howmany do you sample from each strata? This is just to reinforce the points above and to provide some more information about stratified sampling, not to advocate for this approach to be used by students. For some contexts,you may have pre-existing knowledge or data of the population you want to sample from e.g. a list of all the senior students at your schoolvia yourSMS (Student Management System) which also includes other information such as gender, ethnicity, suburb etc., or the Census data, or a data from a previous survey.Given that there is a recognised need to stratify, then pre-existing knowledge like how many Y13and Y12students there are at the school could be used to decide how many year 13 and year 12 students are sampled, so this is proportional to the numbers of each group in the population. What this all means for us, when working in a situation where we get students to sample from a population data set, is that students don't use information from the population data set to inform their sampling method. It would not be appropriate for students to usefeatures/counts from the population data set to inform their stratified sampling method, given that they

item.title: Facebook challenge
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: Can your students predictwhether a Census at School stick person uses Facebook? This post discusses teaching ideas for the Facebookchallenge that Ive set up to support maths week 2016. The aim of this post is to support the use of the challenge within a classroom setting if you wanted to try out the activity, or one similar to it, with your students. I would recommend reading this post -Developing engaging statistical modelling activities: Where do you start?- for more information and references about similar statistical modelling tasks. You can check out the challenge set up for students here: http://mathstatic.co.nz/facebook-challenge Themain stagesof the challenge are: Stage 1.Students are shown 40 CaS stick people, one at a time, in the form of data cards which show information about each stick person EXCEPT whether they use Facebook or not and are asked to predict whether each stick person uses Facebook or not. This stageis to help students engage with the chance aspect of the modelling process, which is in the absence of a model, they are either guessing or using something on the card to inform their decision, however they are not doing this in an organised way. At the end of this part, they will be given feedback on how many they got correct. Note, it is important that this set contains 20 stick people who do use Facebook and 20 stick people who do not use Facebook so that it is unbiased. This part should also help students start to consider what information may be helpful to get their "success rate" at predicting to be above 50%.This stage here is different from the MEAs developed by Garfield et al but I believe important at high school level.This stage in itself is similar to other activities where you investigate a chance only model (or guessing model). I like doing this first, as it sets the idea that in the absence of a model based on additional information, one could just use a model based on the proportion 0.5. Stage 2.Students are given the same 40 CaS stick people in the form of a data set, which now includes whether each stick person uses Facebook or not. This data is linked to iNZight lite, where students can explore how the other variables about each stick person compare for whether they use Facebook or not. For example, they could compare age, snapchat usage, etc. During this part, they need to develop a model (or a set of rules) to apply to predict whether a CaS stick person uses Facebook. If you were working with the students on this activity in class rather than online, you could print out the 40 CaS stick people cards (available here) and get students to physically move the cards around to investigate rules, as well as use software to explore relationships. Using software is also something different from the MEAs developed by Garfield et al.Students should be testing their model/rules on this first set of data, and trying to explain how many they will get correct out of 40 using their model. They should be considering which variable is the "best" at sorting out Facebook users from non-Facebook users. I would not talk about overfitting at this stage as it will be better for the students to learn this when they apply their model to a new set of CaS stick people. Stage 3.Students are given new set of 40 CaS stick people, and repeat stages 1 and 2, with the main difference being that for Stage 1 this time around, students use the model/rules developed to predict whether each stick person uses Facebook or not. How did they go? What success rate did they obtain? Where they better for Facebook users or non Facebook users? They can now take the whole set of 80 CaS stick people and combine together to refine their rules. Stage 4.The challenge ends with one final set of 40 CaS stick people. A student submits whether each stick person uses Facebook or not, along with their email address, an explanation of their process, model, investigation etc. and the email address of the teacher they would like to submit their response to. They are not shown whether each person does use Facebook or not, and are only given a score - the percent correct. The best solution will be published on the site.

item.title: Teaching kids they can be wrong
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=K8MUex70g1M
See customer complaints onhttps://www.facebook.com/PascallNewZealand/
 
Get students to identify all the possible sources of variation for the marshmallows
Take one bag of marshmallows to be a random sample of marshmallows produced from the factory
Is this justified?
Pascial 180g marshmallow bag
13 pink 20 white
20th August (Countdown Mt Roskill)
Yep, we could run a simulation based on 50% chance of each marshmallow being pink or white, run that and compare how many marshmallows out of sets of 33 end up being pink (binomial) but we'd need to assume 50%....
Yet, when we do a confidence interval, we'd be saying the underlying proportion could be anywhere between *** and ***.......
[Note in this case, despite the small number ofMarshmallows, the ratios allow for the use of the norm-based method]
MOE 17.4% - estimating using 1/root(n) - yep it will be a little too big but...
39.4% +/- 17.4%
[22.0, 56.8] so it is plausible that 50% is the underlying proportion for whatever mechanism/process is mixing the pink and white marshmallows
OR, if I run a simulation, using 50% as the proportion of marshmallows that are pink, how often will I find 13 or less pink marshmallows in bags of 33?
Getting 13 or less happened 151 times out of the 1000 times I simulated a bag of 33 marshmallows, where the colour of each marshmallow was either pink or white with 50% probability.
So, I don't have evidence against 50% being the underlying proportion, but ........ does that mean that the underlying proportion is 50%? OR, if I was to use language that our students fall into so easily, is the underlying proportion different from 50%? to which they answer yes or no, no being the same as saying it is 50%
REPEATED sampling
In our teaching, we use lots of modelling. Even with repeated sampling demonstrations (taking new and different random samples from a population) we rely on modelling e.g. population bags, online apps that generate random samples from a defined population like a normal distribution, or tools like the sampling VIT where you can put in your own population and generate random samples. In each of these cases, we do know what the underlying/population parameter is, which is all good and what we need for teaching.
In this case, I truly do not know what the underlying proportion of pink is. I emailed Pascall's to see if they could help, and this is what they sent me in return.
The issue is I have assumed 50%, and not rejected 50%, but why did I use 50% - because there are two colours so it makes sense to assume an even ratio of colours. But I could have easily tested 40% or 33% and also found no evidence against this being the underlying proportion. I went to a workshop in Chicago which was great and this was an approach used to construct the confidence interval. I'm not fully sold on it - there is an issue I see which I'll discuss at some other point - but it is not really an issue for using binomial-ish type situations so for this marhsmallow investigation it sort of works...
so it is not until we get down to 12% or as high as 82% would we start to wonder a
13 pink
18 white
21st August (Pak-n-save Mt Albert)
:-(
Go on - buy a bag of pascall marshmallow for your class and add to this data set - let's see what happens with actual samples of bags
 
So?? Go buy that bag of Pascalls marsmallows, and enter in the number of pink and white below (don't worry if the total is not 33, I'll sort that out later). You'll need to enter your school email so I can check before I accept (there are people out there who just like to spam sites like this..)
Why this?
I'm working on a framework that tries to combine these (at least) two approaches to statistical modelling......

item.title: teaching our subject in a way that reflects what our subject is all about
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: What statistics is has been defined by many many people. I am not going to attempt to present a balanced selection of definitions here. What I do know is that when I was asked to describe what statistics is I couldn't answer. statistics exists because there is variation in the world and we need a way to make sense of it using numbers. our tools are models, but we have these not because they are what is causing the variation but they help us to work better with the variation. statistics as a subject sits apart from other subjects because we are not about determinism (from Maxine). teaching statistics therefore should match this. Yes we use structures (models) in statistics, and yes we use structures in teaching statistics. But why? To make sense of the variation that we see. We need students to experience variation, experience uncertainty so they see a need for the statistical methods we teach them. This is why we care about building statistical concepts so they can understand when and why these methods are useful, and when they are not. It seems to me to be such as contradiction if we teach statistics in a way that doesn't allow our students to experience variation, to experience uncertainty, to appreciate why we build structures and why we use these, and why models are just models, and all models are wrong (to quote George Box). Minimise structure and maximise..... experience? I wrote in an email to a fantastic stats teacher last year the following when asked what I thought about structure It is really something to think about in terms of providing students structures/scaffolds and whether/how this impacts creativity and thinking. I have started to think more about why I dont like overly structural/scaffold approaches in terms of learning rather than just my personal feelings. Related to this, I was talking with another colleague yesterday about my planned workshop and we had a really good discussion about explicit versus hidden curriculum/agenda in teaching. I was saying how when I looked back on my teaching materials to try to work out what I did to teach statistical insight, it wasnt so much that I could see stand out explicit examples or resources/activities or diagrams/SOLO stuff but more about the messages I was giving students that were embedded or hidden in everything else I was doing. The use of structuring in teaching statistics is also really interesting when you think about how we work with data. We start with data and the first thing we want students to appreciate is that there variation and that this means something by connecting to the context why is there variation and what does it mean for these specific variables? Then we try to find models to explain/understand the data by considering structure distributional stuff as well as study design seeing/applying structure. But we cant lose sight of the fact we there will be variation thats why this is statistics hence why our conclusions are always pretty sure in nature. I guess the irony (?) could be that if we focus too much on structure in our teaching of statistics, we are not reinforcing that fundamental understanding that statistics is about variation and differences and that all we are trying to do is come up with ways to deal with the uncertainty and make sense of what we are seeing With this thinking in mind, I think the worry is if we dont start our teaching with the unstructured stuff but instead start with structure, then we would be diminishing variation as the central concept and the whole point of seeing and applying structure in the first place. With all the best intentions in the world, the teaching I see that is very structure driven is missing the Why? stuffand jumps straight into write this do this even think this.. we need to model how to think statistically in our teaching of statistics J Promoting/teaching creativity and independent thought is also considering how even if you can find structure for data, that doesnt mean that is the only structure and that it will remain fixed in the future. So students also need to appreciate they can play around with the structures and create new ones same in our teaching. We need to model a variety of thinking approaches, embrace creativity, empower students to be confident with exploring data independently, enjoy the uncertainty of stats by finding ways to deal with it.. So, my plan for my workshop at the moment is How do you show you care about more than just the assessment when teaching statistics? which is very closely aligned to thinking about the balance between structure (explicit stuff) and thinking (big ideas/values) and also about teaching statistical insight. A premise I have is that if you explicitly focus on the structure in your teaching even if you do care about other things the student will get the message that statistics is not a creative subject and it is a procedural recipe-based assessment-driven subject. Im going from the angle that this is unintentional by teachers to avoid being too confrontational. I dont have all the answers to my question.. but I think the first step would be that you do actually care about more than just the assessment J Im not arguing for no structure but I think it is important for students to be part of the process of engaging with the need for structure, where the motivation is not just in terms of the grade they can get.

item.title: Statistical modelling with pi and prime numbers
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
I know what youmight be thinking. Pi and prime numbers have nothing to do with statistics. Pi is a mathematical constant and numbers are either prime or not.There's no uncertainty here, not like those "grey" or "maybe-ish" answers in stats. So, here are some questions - are the digits of Pi random? Are prime numbers random? What would your students say if you asked them those questions? How do you determine if prime numbers are random? What makes something random? Can you ever "prove" something is random? My first post on this blog was about randomness(seeStatistics teaching ideas based on ... the alphabet!) and I think it's such a core concept that we can never revisit it too many times with students. The idea of a distribution is also super important (in fact, for a great discussion of randomness, distribution, conditioning and mathematics, see this article by Pfannkuch ). Although all probability distributions are distributions, not all distributions are probability distributions. And that is kind of the theme for this statistical investigation.Just because a probability distribution is a good fit to data, doesn't mean that the process that generated that data is random. Exploring the digits of pi Well, according to Wikipedia:
The digits appear to be randomly distributed. In particular, the digit sequence of is conjectured to satisfy a specific kind of statistical randomness, but to date no proof of this has been discovered.
Rather than approach the idea of "random digits" from an entirely theoretical perspective, we could explore this from a statistical modelling perspective. What does randomly distributed mean? If we look at the first thousand digits of pi (0 - 9), and plot the frequencies of each digit,do we see any one digit being used more than another? Remembering that 1000 digits is just a sample of all the digits of pi, we wouldn't expect exactly 100 of each digit. But how much my modelling tool here We can also look at successive pairs of digits, to see if they behave like what we would expect under independence. This distribution appears to have the triangular shape we would expect. Again we can compare this to digits we generate through simulation for a model of independence Basically, we want to check out as much as we can about the real data distribution and if there are any links between digits. For example, I could take differences between the first and third digit, the second and fourth digit etc., or randomly select any two digits from the first 1000 digits and check the difference between these: There is lots more to read about theory driven approaches to prove the randomness of the digits my modelling tool here The thing is, just because these first 1000 digits look similar to what a random process generating digits could produce, does not prove the digits are randomly distributed. For starters, the first digit has to be a 3, and the second digit has to be a 1, and so on, for pi to make sense. Also, very smart people have developed formulae to calculate digits of pi based on their position, which implies a way to directly map an input to and output, without any uncertainty attached to the output (deterministic not stochastic). Just because data looks like data generated from a random process (or a probability model), we can not say that something is random. In this respect, I think looking at something like the digits of pi, for a very deterministic mathematical situation, and showing that the distribution of data can look like some probability distribution in cases when you know randomness is not producing the digits is an essential part of learning about probability modelling. Just because we can conceive of data as being generated from random models, probability models, this does not mean that we believe that it is a random process that creates the real data.
While tests performed on samples can never unequivocally prove that a sequence is random (in fact, we know the digits of pi are not random, since we know formulas to generate them) the apparent randomness in pi is consistent with the idea that it contains all finite sequences (or, at least, all fairly short ones). In particular, if we generate a number from an infinite stream of digits selected uniformly at random, then there is a probability of 100% that such a number contains each and every finite sequences of digits, and pi has the appearance of being statistically random.
http://www.askamathematician.com/2009/11/since-pi-is-infinite-can-i-draw-any-random-number-sequence-and-be-certain-that-it-exists-somewhere-in-the-digits-of-pi/ Modulo prime ..... turns out, not the name of a transformer :-( Brian Hayes, in his postPrime after prime, caught my interest when he said:
The distribution of the primes looks random, with irregular gaps and clusters that seem quite haphazard. If theres a pattern, its inscrutable. As a matter of fact, the primes look random enough that you could play dice with them. Make a list of consecutive prime numbers (perhaps starting with 11, 13, 17, 19, . . . ) and reduce them modulo 7. In other words, divide each prime by 7 and keep only the remainder. The result is a sequence of integers drawn from the set {1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6} that looks much like the outcome of repeatedly rolling a fair die.
So, I did as Brian said :-) I took 108 consecutive primes starting from 11, chucked them into a Google sheet, reduced them modulo 7, and then looked at theintegers that resulted. Here are the first 20 integers:4, 6, 3, 5, 2, 1, 3, 2, 6, 1, 5, 4, 3, 5, 4, 1, 3, 2, 6, 5........ Do they look random? Why don't you take a look at the plot below instead. [caption id="attachment_2207" align="alignnone" width="919"] Figure 1: Plot of the integers generated from using modulo 7 on consecutive primes, starting with 11[/caption] How about this one (from simulating rolls of a fair six-sided die)? [caption id="attachment_2211" align="alignnone" width="919"] Figure 2: Plot of the integers generated from simulating the roll of a fair six-sided die[/caption] I think sometimes we "distributionalise" data too quickly. For this investigationI think it's best to plotthe integers you get from using modulo 7, so students can see this as a process. If we want to start to consider this process as random, then we should not see any patterns in the data. To my eyes, the real integers (Figure 1) look a little bit too nicely behaved, while the simulated integers (Figure 2) looknicely misbehaved :-) We'll come back to this ...... [Note: I used to get students to dothese kinds of graphs FIRST before tally charts, frequency bar graphs, etc., because of the discussion that can be had about randomness, independence, sample space, etc...]. Next, let's compare the distribution of real integers to a distribution of integers generated from simulating the rolling of a fair six-sided die 108 times. Press play on the video below to see the tool in action.   [video width="1014" height="820" mp4="http://teaching.statistics-is-awesome.org/wp-content/uploads/prime3.mp4"][/video]   Some of the distributions of simulated integers do look similar to the distribution of the real integers, but most of the simulated distributions do not. This again suggests that the distribution of real integers, while not NOT looking like the data you could get from a random process, just looks TOO nice. John Cook, who also wrote a post based on Brian's post, uses a chi-square goodness of fit test to show that for a fair six-sided die model ".... the fit is suspiciously good"(seeChi-square goodness of fit test with primes). In my tool, the over-fitted distribution shape from each simulation is tracked in order to build up a visual band of expected variation. Press play on the video below to see what I mean.   [video width="1014" height="820" mp4="http://teaching.statistics-is-awesome.org/wp-content/uploads/prime6.mp4"][/video]   What I think is clearer in these visual representations is the large amount of variability of the outcome frequenciesfor sets of 108 simulated dice rolls. I would hope that students would notice this and wonder about what it means. The result from this informal test is consistent with the formal chi-square goodness of fit test - there is no evidence against the fair six-sided model (the observed counts are all within the "grey fog"). However, as Brian Hayes says in his post:
Theres more to randomness, however, than just ensuring that the results are evenly distributed across the allowed range. Individual events in the series must also be independent of one another. One roll of a die should have no effect on the outcome of the next roll. As a test of independence, we can look at pairs of successive events.
If you take another look at Figure 1, maybe you can see this lack of independence. To explore the idea of independence with the set of 108 integers, we can take the "moving differences" between them (see myGoogle sheet) and then visualise the differences in a dot plot. If we think about the distribution we'd expect for differences when rolling a fair six-side die twice and subtracting the second number from the first... ... the distribution of the moving differences of the integers are not looking that similar. If we use my new simulation-based modelling tool to do an informal goodness of fit test, then I think we can be pretty convinced that there is something going on with these pairs of consecutive prime numbers!   [video width="1242" height="394" mp4="http://teaching.statistics-is-awesome.org/wp-content/uploads/prime12.mp4"][/video]   At this point, I would strongly recommend, if you haven't already, reading all ofBrian Hayes' postPrime after prime. He demonstrates a different visual way to investigateconsecutive primes, which is pretty cool. Additionally, Brian goes into more of the research that has been conducted into this fascinating area of prime numbers and randomness, including a great list of reference articles.
