item.title: Is there a causal relationship between how many times you repeat something and......
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This post was inspired by a media article that made me think: How do you teachcorrelation is not causation? Statistics in the news The media article used for this post isVisualising the relation between NZ voters and parties (NZ Herald).Click on through, read the article, have a play with the interactive graph, and then come backhere if you're still interested:-) Why the world needs teachers..... Hopefully, when viewing the graph accompanying the article, you were met with several warnings regarding interpreting correlation. Hmmmm, how many times have you told students the safe data message that correlation is not the same as causation, but still read with teacher disappointment statements of a causal inference nature within their report? Because you are a teacher, you know that just repeating something over and over again doesn't mean that students will understand it. You also know what happens if you tell a student notto do something :-) However, when I started to think about what examples I have used toteach that correlation is not the same as causation, for nearly every example I could find at least one issue with the message students might actually take away. So let's go through my thinking....... assuming that students "get" the basic idea that correlation measures the strength of the linear association between two variables and that it only means something if the data itself looks linear (e.g. eyes first, correlation coefficient second). I bet you've shown graphs like the ones found on thespurious correlations page or used examples like "number of burglaries" vs "number ofice creams sold" and discussed how a variable like temperature which is possibly linked to the time of year is why we see this statistical relationship.You've probably given notes about correlation like the ones on thewebsite linked to for "more information"from within the article and hoped students get it....... but why should they believe you that correlation does not equal causation?  
  • We need to show students with data why we have this warning (and it's not how you think!)
  • We need to teach students to be unhappy if they can't change representations
  • We need to teach students its not just scatterplots that should have this warning e.g. males rates themselves as higher for confidence..... um and so do people in sports teams..... so???
  • You should be made to go through quite a few pop up boxesthat remind you many many times that "correlation is not causation" before you get to play with the data (well unless you "end the tour"). There is also a very nice warning about the limitations of the data and"hazards of individual vs. aggregate correlation". Discuss with students why these warning have been included with the data visualisation.
  • Show about "correlation is not causation". Does this contain similar data? Would this make sense to someone not sure about what this statement means? Shouldn't it be called "stats is fun"? Just kidding.....
  • Ask the students why you can only use one display Even if you understand (or think you understand) how correlation is not causation, you are only allowed to explore the data using one type of display (a scatterplot) and the scatterplot you are presented with does not let you explore more than two variables at the same time, which I think is the main reason why students form causation inferences in the first place. Additionally, you have to view the data filtered by one of the political parties, so you are forced into a situation where you are looking at a subgroup with no option to see what the relationship looks like for everyone.
  • I'm sure you've probably seen the spurious correlations pageand had a chuckle at some of the crazy correlations. In your teaching, maybe you've asked your students what might be the third variable that links the variables shown in the graph.
  • The mathisfun sitegives an example of icecream sales vs sunglases sold, and states - does this mean that sunglasses make people want icecream? I find these examples too simplistic..... The warning about correlation is not causation can't just appeal to whether we believe it or not e.g. we don't believe that sunglasses would make someone buy icecream, nor do we believe that nicolas cage films cause people to drown
  • But then take this exampleWhat's warming the world?- Visually it looks like the spurious correlation above, so why do we think about it differently? Shouldn't students also be questioning the conclusions based on observational data?

item.title: older rant report comments
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This is a non-serious post about writing report comments for statistics (and mathematics) students.
Writing report comments - a brief history of my approach thus far
A good friend of mine (also a teacher) once commented that I spent more time thinking and creating tools to write report comments than the actual time it would take to just write them by hand. I did write my report comments "by hand" for the first couple of years of teaching, but then I realised that, while every student is different, I wasn't necessarily using completely different comments about each student. There was a structure to what I was writing and some key things I was commenting on regarding what the student was doing (or not doing) in terms of their learning. So a started developing tools to help me write my report comments.
When I was deaning for a couple of years, I got to read a HUGE amount of comments across a range of subjects. The worst comments I read were ones where the teacher:
wasn't using a good structure for their comments wasn't using a good spelling and grammar checking tool wasn't using evidence like achievement, attendance, work completion, class contributions as the basis for their comments Basically, the comment as a whole wasn't being checked to see if the separate sentences together made for an overall cohesive piece of writing that was actually informative (and accurate) about the specific student and their learning. I actually wrote a "SOLO guide to writing report comments" which I privately used to score report comments that I read :-)
When I became HOD, I wanted our department to produce high quality comments, so created a report writing tool that was based on a four sentence structure. For example a mid-year formative report comment, each sentence was defined as follows:
Overall comment about the student in terms of attitude, effort and achievement Subject specific comment based on statistics-specific learning outcome (in turn based on NZC achievement objective) and using symbols, language and text (KC) Key competency comment around thinking, participating and contributing, relating to others, managing self Feed forward comment based on advice for areas to work on to improve learning Our department created a set of comments for each type of sentence, and teachers could select one from each as the basis for their report comment. In my opinion, what made this approach better than other report writing tools out there is that it incorporated a structure to the report comment. It provided a good starting point for teachers, and for those new to writing report comments, or not as confident with writing in English, some good examples of accurate communication.
I know that teachers would love to be able to write much more personal comments that parents could actually understand and that students could actually use to make substantial gains in their learning. Some schools do have this approach but for many, the focus of report comments is more on the formality and correctness of the communication.
It's interesting for me now to compare how I worked with teachers to improve their writing of report comments, with how I worked with statistics students to improve their writing of reports. With both I would focus on the structure of the writing - what were the key components, how did they fit together, what were the links or relationships etc. But in my work with students, I never gave them a tool to write reports using a comment bank. Does this make me a hypocrite?
Well, I'm not sure. It's not entirely true that I didn't give students examples of statements to write in their reports, because of course I did as part of the teaching and learning programme. But I think the key reason why I approached working with teachers writing report comments and students writing reports about statistical investigation differently was because I saw the written output as being assessed differently. Simply put - for teachers, I valued accurate communication more than creativity or thinking. For students, I valued creativity and thinking more than accurate communication.
In terms of how a teacher is assessed on their report comment writing, the most important thing is that the report comment is an accurate and objective communication of what has been observed about a student's learning (e.g. correct spelling of student name, no grammar or spelling mistakes, follows school conventions for report writing, matches grades and attendance, identifies what the student has done to help their learning, identifies what they need to do to improve their learning, etc.). The report comment is not primarily assessed on the level of creativity, thinking or even personal insight the teacher has of the student, even if we as teachers think it should be.
In terms of how a student is assessed on their report writing, the most important thing (in my opinion) is that the report is a communication of what the student was thinking before, through and after the statistics investigation (e.g. what decisions did they make, why did they make these, what did they learn, what knowledge did they use, how does this link to the real world etc.). This communication does need to demonstrate the student has good conceptual understanding of the relevant statistics concepts, but this should not take over the whole point of the student writing in the first place.
Hmm..... just like student report comments really....
The new report writing tool
My goal with this new version of the report writing tool was to make the process more natural and for comments to be "suggested" in the writing process rather than having to be selected. I have not forced teachers into writing with a certain structure but have instead placed a SOLO diagram beside the writing area to remind teachers what aspects to include. I've also made a video to explain how to use the tool.

item.title: How many apps could a teenager possibly need?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: Or, more practically, how many apps could a teenager possibly have on their smartphone? I was considering this a few days ago when my iPhone informed me there was no memory left to film a video on my phone. When I reviewed my data usage, I saw how many MBs each app was taking up on my 16GB phone and I was supersurprised. I ended up deleting quite a few apps - most I hadn't used for over a year anyway. It got me thinking about the typical size of an iPhone app...... which got me thinking about how to get this data! I did a bit of a search first to see if anyone else already had the data and found this articlehttp://techcrunch.com/2015/02/12/ios-app-size-limit/-which is interesting but doesn't give me data! However, the article did inform me that there is an upper limit to the apps available for download on iTunes - 4GB. Although, if you want it to be downloadable via the web, the maximum size is 100MB. So I continued my search for data.... I headed to https://itunes.apple.com/us/genre/ios/id36which appeared to give me an online catalogue of apps available for download from the US App Store (owned by Apple). But how to use this to obtain a sample of apps and then record their size (and other interesting information)? That's when having a bit of a poke around on the site and examining the URL for each app comes in handy. For example, after looking at different apps for sale, I saw that each app has a unique idwhich forms part of the URL e.g.https://itunes.apple.com/us/app/id414215658.If these ID numbers are allocated sequentially, then this sequence can be used to create a sampling frame, from which you can randomly select ID numbers from to use to get your sample. Unfortunately, this is not the case with the itunes store :-( Sometimes it can be sort of efficient to try this approach anyway and just move on if the id number doesn't give you an actual result or that product is no longer available, but with over 900 million possible permutations I think this approach may be super inefficient. So what next? After familiarising myself with the online catalogue, I found thatthere are 24 categories for the apps, each category has an initial "popular page" and the ability to pull up apps by their first letter/number (with as many pages as needed for each first letter/number, with the apps listed in alphabetical order). On each page are listed a maximum of186 apps (three columns of 62 apps each). Since I can't use a simple random sampling method, I needed to use some sort ofmulti-stage sampling approach (I won't go into the details here but let me know if you want the full description). Since this blog is all about teaching statistics, and BYOD (Bring Your Own Device) apps for phones/ipads/tablets being the new normal, I thoughtthe Education categorycould be a good focusfor this data. Plus, it won't take as long to sample from if I focus on one category - although Education is a big category for iPhone apps. You might want to consider that before creating your own app with dreams of making it big from selling education-related software :-) At the end of the post is the current data (as of 11th April 2016) for a random sample of the Education apps available for sale from the US App Store (owned by Apple).For each app, I have recorded its name, whether it is free or paid, its cost if paid (in $USD), the version number, when it was last updated, it's size in MB, the compatability description, how many ratings it has received, and....... For comparison reasons, I have also obtained the same information from the Education apps listed on the "popular page". These "popular apps" are not a random sample but it could be interesting to compare the various features of the random sample of education apps to the set of popular apps. Of course, to even start to modelhow many apps a teenager could possibly have on their smartphone you'd need to also model how much of their phone memory they are using to store selfies (and other photos), videos and music, and how much data each app itself generates after it is installed. So I'll leave that exploration to you..... Show me the data! Here is the data, but you'll have to get to it through iNZight lite ;-)

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: How many apps could a teenager possibly need?

item.title: What are you assessing?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: I was driving to work this morning, thinking about the various questions I have been asked, and a range of posts/questions I have seen, lately about NCEA statistics assessment. I was considering how I might add to a current discussion around AS91584 Evaluate statistically based reportsregarding why students may not be performing as well as we might have expected in the external assessment. Somewhere between Dominion Rd and Symonds St I realised that perhaps the bigger issue was around what we are assessing in our tasks, or more importantly what we think we are assessing. My personal philosophy for NCEA statistics internals Achieved should be a given. By this, I do not mean that every student should get achieved, but that every student should have all the information they need to know what is expected for them to achieve the standard, which translates to each student knowing what is necessary for them to communicate about their investigation. I don't believe that the point of an internal assessment task is to test if students can remember the stages of PPDAC, nor whether they can recall the details of what they should produce or how they should communicate within each part of their report. What I think should be assessed, and what I think we should be looking for as teachers in student work, is how well students apply these methods to a new situation, context, data set and purpose. When I use the word "methods" here I am including bothstatistical methods and reporting/communication methods - basically what to do and how to write about it (interpret it). Achieved under the NCEA standards is pretty much following each of the steps, which requiresmeeting each of the bullet points under EN3, and producing a report that is statistically sound. Ultimately, the students are assessed based on what theycommunicate. So why do you hate cut and paste reports and exemplars so much Anna? I've added this heading because those teachers who have worked closely with me already know this, and it is important to share this bias with you all. So let meexplain why I am very wary of materials and resources that promote "cut and paste" reporting writing/communicating and examples of merit and excellence writing. It's not that exemplars themselves that are the issue in my opinion, it is how they are used by teachers and students. In short, there isn't enough material that supports how to use them in teaching (the during stuff), only in theassessment (the final stuff), which completely makes sense because they are assessment focused, they are about how to mark the assessment. But this is why I am not super impressed when I see resources that take material based onhow it is marked and use it to exemplifyhow it is taught.It's up there with resources that start off with how to write a problem for a context without exploring the awesomeness of that context first. The structure is there to help not dictated. Remember, statistics is all about structure + variation, so our teaching should be like this too! Don't expect to assess understanding through reports (THE assessment) - assess it as part of your teaching (formative assessment) Every year there seems to be a question about how important it is whether a student has talked about sampling variability in their report/assessment for any of the inference achievement standards. I can't be the only one who's eyes get bigger when I read something like "The only thing the student didn't do was......... can I still give them achieved?" when talking about something like sampling variability, because of course it is so fundamental to understanding sample to population inference. However, let's just think about this for a moment. Ifwhatwe are assessing in a report is the final product - a statistically sound summary of what methods were done with an interpretation of the results of these methods, why would we expect a student to write aboutwhy the method is being used. Unless we have taught this justification as anotherwhat to write component of the report of course. In which case, we can not claim that a student writing a statement like "If I took another sample, I would get a different median......." actually means they understandwhy the method has been used. What has this got to do with AS91584? The key thing about this achievement standard is that students are being assessed on. There is not reporting of them being assessed, they are not being supported to write correctly and perform methods as required for a report, they have to think about whats, whys and hows for the entire assessment. While in an internal, because the nature of the assessment is a report, it is fine to use stock statements to meet the criteria of statistical soundness, that is notwhatAS91584 assessment is all about. The examiner's report for each of the years this standard has been assessed clearly states that students are not using the information in the report, and are not integrating statistical and contextual knowledge. So what do we assess then? I'm not going to end this post with the magical answer. But what I would suggest is some homework. Give your students (or teachers in your department) an exemplar report for one of thestatistics inference standards e.g. AS91035. Then give them a completely different situation, context, and data set, and explicitly tell them to copy the exemplar, but change words where necessary to make it match the new situation. Then read what they have written. Then ask yourself.............. What am I really looking for in their writing? What I will conclude with is that when I adopted this philosophy, I found that my expectations and demands for student writing actually increased (not decreased as I suspect many will think), because I expected the basics to be correct - what I really wanted to see washow this made sense for the data, context, purpose of their investigation.

item.title: Creating a model for number of syllables in a word
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
Nice little activity to see if you can model stuff, but it will not work all the time....
Also could be tied to word difficulty in English
http://codegolf.stackexchange.com/questions/47322/how-to-count-the-syllables-in-a-word
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/9096228/counting-syllables-in-a-word
https://www.twinword.com/blog/how-to-check-english-word-difficulty/
http://journals.sagepub.com/doi/abs/10.1111/j.1467-9280.1996.tb00336.x
http://stackoverflow.com/questions/5141092/determine-the-difficulty-of-an-english-word
Why would you want to know about syllables per word?
Link to the NZ herald that has the number of minutes an article will take to read. Does this take into account the difficulty of words, or just the number of words?
(1) Given a list of forty words (random selection of 40 from this list of statistics related words in English), go through and write how many syllables each word has - how did you decide on the number of syllables? (a) say the word (b) other method _________
(2) Without saying the word, is there another way we could get the number of syllables the word has, using features of the word itself. Let's start with the number of letters.
(3) Show plot showing the 40 words in terms of number of syllables compared to number of letters.
Simplify the problem down to two or three syllable words (?) and treat the number of syllables as a categorical variable e.g. use words
Show this plot.
(4) Look at what words work and what don't in a table format, after annotating the graph before, to show ranges of letters...... table can help get head around overall success rate of model, and also conditional stuff
(5) Give the model (rules) a go with a different set of 40 words - (using a little bit of code like criteria to define model) - run through - then mark each one correct or not
(6) Another approach might be to use the number of vowels in the word

item.title: Who cares is A is bigger than B?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
I have this working theory that one of the reasons why students don't always make the right call when using sample-to-population inference methods (that includes interpreting confidence intervals) is that there really is just no reason for them to care about getting it right (apart from maybe the assessment grade).
We want students to care about sampling variability and thus realise that they are probably wrong if they use the sample medians only to make a comparison about which population tends to be bigger. But what if the question posed itself means nothing to them, so they really don't care if they make the wrong call?
We tried creating tasks at my previous school to motivate students to care. Here are some examples:
* A newspaper takes a random sample of Year 12 students from our school and another school, and based on this sample concludes the other school has smarter Year 12 students because the median number of credits gained in the previous year was higher for the sample of students from the other school.
* The principal took a random sample of Year 12 and Year 13 students and asked them how long they studies for the recent mid-year exams. Because the Year 13 students sampled, on average (using the median), studied for longer, he gives them a mufti day but not the Year 12 students.
* The principal (yep he got some use in our classes!) doesn't think students are donating a gold coin when they wear mufti (the condition of wearing mufti on mufti day). He takes a random sample of students and finds the median amount donated was only 50c. The principal cancels mufti days for the rest of the year.
What was interesting is that the contexts did engage students, but their go to default arguing position was not "hey, you need to consider sampling variability" but "hey you need to consider this particular cause, or this particular cause....". The random sampling notion was not there, nor was the stance "assume all variation is chance variation unless convinced otherwise".
To me, any attempt to help students practice interpreting I dont believe you can meaningfully practice the skill of interpretation for inference in isolation from (1) the problem driving the investigation, which is written about a population set in a real context, (2) the uncertainty attached to answering this problem about the population because youre only using sample data on the variable and (3) actually caring about getting the answer right which needs a context and problem where it matters whether you can make a call or not.

item.title: Do something today that your future self will thank you for
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
Some time in 2015, I stumbled across the platformIFTTT (if this than that). It's an amazing cool way to collect data from a range of services without having to write any code. For example, you can set up "applets":
  • to save all tweets made by a specific user to a Google spreadsheet
  • to save details of any auction listed on eBay with the word "calculator" to a Google spreadsheet
  • to log how long you spend at work each day in a Google spreadsheet
and so much more. You'll notice a theme of theapplets I have been using - they are all ones that automatically save data to a Google spreadsheet. Since the data gets saved when triggered by defined events (e.g. someone posts a tweet), you'll need some patience while you wait for the data to be collected. My advice - take a look today, set up a fewapplets and then let them do their thing over the rest of the year. Then, your future self will be extremely grateful next year! As a demo, I've recently set up anapplet that records tweets from @tuureti(a twitter bot developed by Thomas Lumley). From each tweet, I'm extracting how many buses were on the road in Auckland and what percentage of them were on time, and

item.title: These are a few of my favourite things
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
I miss a lot of things about teaching high school statistics and mathematics. Not writing report comments (well, actually, maybe a little....) but lots of other things. What is interesting to me when reflecting on what kind of learning activities I miss is that most of my favourite ones are very low tech. All of them require students working in groups of two or more, and all require students to talk to each other as part of the activity. My teaching of large lectures is often me talking and students listening. These lectures are recorded and viewed online, which I guess just makes me a "youtube teacher", albeit a well paid one. So, here are a few of my favourite classroom teaching things with a quick example of each.
(1) sorting or matching card activities
I'm not really talking about vocab based matching card activities but graph based activities

item.title: What is good professional development for statistics teachers?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: At the beginning of this month, I was fortunate to be able to attend the Joint Statistical Meetings in Baltimore. The first session I attended was a panel on theDesign, Implementation, and Impact of Different Approaches to Professional Development for Teachers of Statistics.The speakers were fantastic and shared a wide range of strategies and ideas for how to help support statistics teachers. In this post, I am going to try to summarise some key themes across the different talks and subsequent discussion, and how these relate to the New Zealand teaching context. The role of professional organisations and associations The role of universities and tertiary education providers The role of researchers The role of government agencies The role of teachers What do teachers want for PD? Jane Watson Rachel Passmore My research

item.title: Do we always need real-life contexts when teaching statistics?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
For this post, I want to make it clear from the beginning that I am not really sure what my answer is to this question. I have been a strong advocate foralwayshaving context for learning in statistics, but I think I am motivated because I don't want calculations-onlystuff.I know that there are times when context can get in the way of building statistical ideas (e.g. Pfannkuch, ****). I suspect what might help is a simple framework - why do we value context so much? There are mathematical modelling frameworks. A framework I have proposed that is might help with statistics are our rightly obsession with data is below Are these problems valuable for teaching statistics? Have a read of this problem shared on Twitter by @jamestanton:

Three points chosen at random inside a circle. What is the prob they all lie in some half of the circle (that is, on one side of some diam)?

James Tanton (@jamestanton) August 12, 2017
In the problem are some key "statistical" words like "random" and "prob". If I use a theoretical approach to solve the problem, "mathematical thinking" will win terms of what kind of knowledge and strategies I will use to solve the problem. If I use a simulation-based approach to estimate the probability, I still think "mathematical thinking" will win, as any variation I will observe in the data I generate through simulation is a by-product of using a simulation-based approach, not helpful to understanding the variation in the original situation - which is about three particular points chosen at random (not an ongoing real-life process etc.) What is the answer you might be asking? Well, the first two points can be anywhere in the circle, as you always draw the diameter such as that they both lie on the same side (or on the diameter itself). The maximum distance between any two points in a circle has to be the diameter of the circle.   JS Bin on jsbin.com

item.title: Online data-ing
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This post is part of a series of posts where I'm going to share some strategies for getting real data to use for statistical investigations that require sample to population inference. As I write them, you will be able to find them all on this page. O data, data, wherefore art thou data? Who hasn't spent hours online in the quest for the holy grail of datasets? In many instances, even when you do happen to find datasets that no one else has found and used before, the background information about the data is scarce, the data is not relevant to students or there are not enough "good" categorical or numerical variables. More often than not,the data was collected in some dubious manner, which means considerations (1) (2) and (3) below are out the window:
  1. You need a clearly defined and nameable population.
  2. You need a sampling frame that is a very close match to your population.
  3. You need to select from your sampling frame using a random sampling method to obtain the members of your sample.
  4. You need to define and measure variables from each member of the sample/population so the resulting data is multivariate.
Another aspect of shared datasets that often disappoints me is when no attribution is provided about where the data came from. As teachers, we have to model good practice to our students and teach students about data ownership, privacy and appropriate methods to access data. So what is my magical solution to the problem of online data-ing? One of my suggestions is to stop searching for datasets that already exist and starting making them yourself. I think it's quite fun to do, given you put aside some time to do it so you're not under pressure. Creating the dataset yourself also means that you know about the context and population to provide good background information (and guide students to inform themselves with further contextual knowledge if needed) for the task. Of course, it's easy for me to say "start making them yourself" because I have the skills to do so.
  • Use a service like IFTTT
  • Scrap data from a website
  • Access data through an API
I reckon the best way to start is to pick a theme and branch out from there. For me, the theme is sometimes inspired by an article I've read, a conversation I've had, something students have been talking about or something I've seen on Twitter. A couple of times I've contacted organisations or authors of papers that I've read and they have provided me with data. Most of the time though, I've ended up finding the data online in some shape or form and pulling it together myself. That doesn't mean I've been able to find everything I tried searching for but it does mean that my search is guided by something I think will be interesting. For some reason lately I've been interested in all things pet related, particularly dogs vs cats. So, in this post, I'll focus on creating a population data set -(1) (2) and (4) - usingthe theme of dogs and cats.I will use a little bit of technology and Excel to create the dataset but no R (I'll save that for a later post!) Splash dogs I came across the tweet below a little while back:

scraping and visualizing dog dock jumping data #rstats https://t.co/IeLQaOsdNW pic.twitter.com/PgcipbnuWH

Luis D. Verde (@LuisDVerde) July 15, 2017
Like I think many others who read the post, I tried to access the data Luis used for his visualisations and at that time, the website would not open (it works fine now). So instead I looked for another source of similar data and found the Ultimate Air Dogs site. They have results from their competitions available as well as other important information about how the events are run and how the results are recorded. They also have a cute promotional video on YouTube: The results I ended up using came from the archives pageand the file 2016 BY DOGS NAME. These results represent the best long dock jump for each dog who competed in any UAD event over the 2016 season. Since the results are given as a PDF, I used a free online PDF to Excel converter to create the initial dataset. Since I wanted it to be clear that the cases are the dogs, I removed the first two columns which gave details about each dog's owners. You can see that the age variable is not consistently measured - sometimes years, sometimes months - and the breed column has some interesting codes in there too. I started with the easiest "cleaning" and converted the jumps from feet and inches to metres. I also created a variable for the number of letters used in each dog's name (I removed any guidance given about how to pronounce the name that some dog owners had provided). I then cleaned up the age column (converted all ages to years, accurate to one decimal place) and the sex column (there was a mix of lower and upper case letters). Another variable I would really like is the number of syllables in each dog's name, but since there are over 1500 dogs in this dataset, I will leave this up to you and your students to measure :-) At this stage, I had some good numerical variables, but the categorical variables needed some work to ensure a nice multivariate dataset (4). The variable ST is the US state the dog comes from (well mostly, there are a couple of dogs in there from Canada!), so I created a variable called US region with five levels: West, Midwest, Northeast, South and non-US using information from census.gov. That involved finding a reference table like the one below and the Excel function VLOOKUP: Making sense of the dog breed codes took more work. I found the the instructions given to owners about writing the codes on the UAD website but could not find a reference table to link the dog breed codes to their full descriptions. I googled "UAD dog abbreviations" and found a table here. Using a similar process as above (convert PDF to Excel, use VLOOKUP to match dog codes to full descriptions, etc.) I attempted to turn these unfamiliar two/three letter codes into dog breeds. This was the only time consuming part of this process, as not all the codes were on the reference table (so I also used this table from UKC), and how the codes were written by owners was really inconsistent. I decided to describe all breeds as mixed if they listed more than one code since I had no information about whether one was more dominant than the other. I'm not 100% I've got all the codes matching up to breeds correctly, so any dog breed experts out there are more than welcome to get in touch to let me know what I've done wrong :-) Getting the dog breed descriptions also didn't help me in creating a categorical variable that could be used nicely for comparison (i.e. for sample to population inference involving two means/medians). This is a large population dataset but even so, I wouldn't want any more than maybe five levels per categorical variable. So the last thing I did was find a reference table that classified dogs in terms of their size based on their breed (this table from UKC) and used this information to create another variabledog type. And now we have a population dataset :-) The population isAll dogs who competed in UAD during 2016 (1), the spreadsheet provides the sampling frame for this population (2), and there are a variety of "usable" numerical and categorical variables (4).You can go and take a random sample from this population using my BYOP sampler tool:mathstatic.co.nz/sampler-new/ZCECNSEL(there's more information about the BYOP sampler tool here). Updated this to include data fromhttp://www.akc.org/dog-breeds/ for dog size and dog energy levels. [Something related to dogs which I think could be used as part of a class activity to support this task is this great visualisation from Information is Beautiful:Best in show - what's the top dog?] Where to next? This example has focused on situations where the results for an event are already available in one file that you can download, clean, and add new variables to by using data from other sources or from the variables you have.There are lots of events - sporting or otherwise - where the results are shared online in one file. You could try following the steps I described to see if you can create a similar dataset for 2015 using thefile 2015 BY DOGS NAME.
item.category: Finding real data for real data stories (sample to population inference)

item.title: facts vs data
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
During the first week of the Term 3 holidays, I had the privilege of attending NZAMT down in Christchurch. Towards the end of the week, I tweeted this... ... which at the time I was pretty excited about. There were some dinners with really interesting discussion around statistics vs maths, some workshops with some interesting literature and discussion around statistics vs maths, and some key notes where speakers (perhaps without realising) offered up interesting examples of statistics vs maths. facts vs data is what it seems to me to be the issue. maths and stats both require reasoning, communication, using models etc., but we giving students situations where it is not clear when we want them to trust the information or not trust the information in terms of its certainty. It's not just the answers might vary - variability in output - but that the models themselves are built on parameters that we don't know for sure what the values should be. If we are building and using models with a view "facts" then we areprobably doing mathematics. Within stats we still have this problem due to our history of maths integration. Probability questions are the best and worst place to find this conflicting message. Take this example:
A company that sells coffee beans recorded the number of visits to its website in 15-minute periods over the last two months. The company found that in 96% of such periods, there was at least one visit to the website. Calculate the probability that the website will receive more than 10 visits in any given 30-minute period. [NZQA AS91586 2014 Q3(c)]
Note the question asks for "the probability" which could be the first signal that the information presented about this situation is considered as "facts" (although even if it said estimate this might still be the case - the verb used doesn't change the presentation of "facts" vs "data"). The problem is one we teachers would refer to asInverse Poisson, requiring students to use the formula, use P(X = 0) and then rearrange etc. to find lamda. The focus of this problem is the calculation using a model -Poisson - for who knows whatever reason. The thing is, all we are working with is data that are not facts. Two months of 15-minute periods is a lot of data, but does the website get visits 24 hours a day? What is the shape of the sample distribution data? Why are we using Poisson as a model in the first place? Why don't we just use the data we have, re-unitise it to 30 minute periods, and calculate the proportion of 30 minute periods that had more than 10 visits? Why set up a model and then use this to get a "precise" answer that is anything but? Now, after some follow up emails and re-examination of materials, I feel really bad for students. NZAMT week I presented three workshops all based around a framework I developed as part of my Masters research. The short story behind the framework is that we need to move beyond theoretical vs experimental comparisons. Our curriculum and assessment require students to grapple with true vs model vs experimental.. but it is actually more than this. We need four components if we really want to be clear when we are modelling or not. Here is one example that I have been teasing apart recently... You collect some data e.g. number of emails received per hour. You wonder if a Poisson distribution would be a suitable model. What do you use for the parameter of your model, your lambda? Your best estimate is the sample mean (although you would lose a degree of freedom in doing this if you were to test the fit of your model using chi-square). An interesting thing has emerged with some teachers I've spoken to. Rather than calculate the sample mean, some teachers use the proportion of 0s in the sample data and then use the formuale for the Poisson distribution (inverse Poisson) to find lambda. Huh? Why? This assumes the Poisson distribution is a match to your sample data before you've even tested that it matches.... the logic to me seems really flawed. But then I remembered there is a history of non-modelling Poisson distribution questions which focus on maths and calculations e.g. inverse calcuations with the formula! Aha, and this is the problem. On one hand we are saying these distributions are models, not exact, not perfect etc. and then on the other hand we reinforce notions of preciseness and exactness by using algebra and maths to "determine" values like lamda, mean and standard deviation..;... 2014 prob dist paper Q3(c) A company that sells coffee beans recorded the number of visits to its website in 15-minute periods over the last two months. The company found that in 96% of such periods, there was at least one visit to the website. Calculate the probability that the website will receive more than 10 visits in any given 30-minute period. 2016 prob dist paper Q3(a)(ii) Between 6 am and 10 pm each day, using footage from its security cameras, the supermarket found that in 94% of 5-minute periods, there was at least one shopper arriving at the supermarket. Discuss how the mean number of shoppers who arrive at the supermarket per 5 minutes between 6 am and 10 pm compares to the mean number of shoppers who arrive at the supermarket per 5 minutes between 10 pm and 6 am.

item.title: Fighting for the underdog that is Informal Inferential Reasoning (IIR)
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: I first decided to write this post because of some discussion within a stats teacher Facebook group about the informal rules of thumb we've developed for the New Zealand statistics curriculum. I wasn't sure that one of the rules of thumb - often referred to as the DBM/OVS rule - was getting a fair deal, hence the "underdog" reference in the post title. So I started writing some thoughts, explanations and examples. And then I stopped. Because I realised that everything I was writing someone has either written about or presented about, and made available through the Senior Secondary Guide, CensusAtSchoolNZ, or some other public forum. Yes, there is a lot of material out there and it's not always easy to judge the good from the bad, so you could expect some teachers to miss some of the good stuff. But surely in a country of our size, with increasing collaboration between schools and teachers, the good would outweigh the bad, and it would be harder and harder to miss out on the key messages at the core of teaching informal inferential reasoning, right? So, what's going on? Well, having just finished teaching our intro stats course over summer school, which culminated in the use of formal inferential methods, I just can't get my head around the idea that there is no purpose to teaching informal inferential reasoning because all of that stuff gets replaced by formal methods anyway.   Informal inferential reasoning is all about the journey not the destination (making the call). Seriously? Have you tried to help a student understand the F-test? Do you know what reasoning you try to tap into? Put picture of three boxplots with Looks pretty similar to the DBM/OVS approach to me. Here's why informal inferential reasoning is so important. (1) Despite it's application to "make calls" it's really more about exploring features of samples and from repeated sampling building up generalisations of what typically happens when you sample. This reasoning isn't restricted to F-tests, which you could, quite rightly, dismiss as being beyond high school level anyway thus supporting an argument not to teach DBM/OVS. It's just like essential stuff. When either we compare two things, we use some sort of measure like the medians for each group, see how different they are, and then think about explanations for the difference. Our default (well, actually our default should be something about data quality.... .but anyway) is to consider a simply chance explanation. Students want to use a default like a contextual reason or even worse a causal reason. Our struggle (hopefully productively) is to convince students their default should also be "just chance". We can't convince students of this by using the rules first without any exploration of where the rules came from.

item.title: Come on get app-y!
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: I'm going to be using the Google Quick! Draw! data cardswith my stats class and want to collect similar-ish data from my students to compare. Since I need to develop an app for this, I thought I should write up how to do this in case anyone else wanted to give it a go. So come on get app-y and let's write a web app that captures data related to drawing :-) Part 1: A starter web app Let's start by creating a simple web app using Google Apps Script. All you need is a Google account :-) Head to Google Drive and create a new Google sheet calledDrawingApp.The Google sheet will be where all our data is saved. Add a column headingcalledThingin cell A1. To get data into our sheet via an app, we'll need a script so open theScript editor under the Tools menu (Tools --> Script editor).

item.title: What's chance got to do got to do with it?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
I've been teaching randomisation-based inference methods since 2006. I found one of my very early teacher workshops and the Excel spreadsheet I used to demonstrate randomisation (permutation) tests and (1) the VBA code still worked and (2) I realised I haven't really evolved too much. If anything, I have reduced the scope of what I teach in an effort to try to make the key ideas "more clearer" but I'm not convinced this is working.
I have the privelege of designing and teaching a brand new intro stats and data science course this semester. We are nearly six weeks into a 12 week semester, and the last three weeks have been all about randomisation tests. I have made the effort to NOT stick to a template for interpretation, a generic script, or any fill in the blanks approach to constructing arguments.
I thought I would share some of the activities I used to try to get a better feeling for "just chance".
My students struggle with just chance or chance acting alone and I don't blame them. When I sat down and went through all the examples I had used in teaching, I
The biggest realisation for me is my students asking what chance has got to do with it. They themselves when they did the activities were not making decisions by chance. Yes, we can present the logic of "doing better than a coin" or "doing better than a monkey" (e.g. Hans Rosling!), but if coins and monkeys are not the things doing the study who cares??

item.title: Statistics teaching ideas based on ..... the alphabet!
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This postfocuses on randomness, simulations and probability. 10 quick ideas......
  1. Choose five letters (e.g. A, B, D, N, U) and display these together. For the rest of these ideas to work, choose letters that can go together to make three letter words (avoid certain words!). Ask students to randomly select one of the letters and write this down.
  2. Ask students to share honestly how they selected their letter - you should find they do use a reason e.g. the first letter of their name, or they choose the one they think no one else will select. Discuss the difference between selecting something and randomly selecting something, and get students to come up with examples for each e.g. selecting which lolly to eat based on which one you like vs putting your hand into a bag and choosing a lolly without looking.
  3. Youcould discuss more how humans are not that great at generating or accepting randomness. There are some greatyoutube videosand websites with ideas for activities to explore this. A nice example is this decision bySpotify to change their algorithm for shuffling songs- their article includes some nice visualisations to support their discussion. You could also explore how the word or concept of random is used in everyday language, or in particular, in design (like my example below).
  4. Display the class results as a dot plot (with the letters along the horizontal axis). So what are we looking for in the plot? Ask the students - are these results what you expect? Some students may discuss expecting to see an equal number of selections for the five letters, others may expect to see uneven results because "it's random", others may have other ideas based on not trusting that other students selected their letters randomly. Try to get as much out of your students as possible so you know what they are thinking :-)
  5. We can't use the results to prove that students selected their letters randomly or not, but we can see if the resultslook like what we'd get if a random process was used. Students may not know what they are looking for, and for small samples like a class, we actually expect quite a bit of variation. Use asimulation tool like thisone to simulate randomly selecting n letterswith replacementfrom the five letters you used (n being the size of your class). Discuss with the class whether their results look similar or different to the simulated results.
  6. Make five large cards with each of the five letters on them. Select three students from the class (randomly or not!) and use a shuffling process to allocate each student one of the five cards. Get your students to stand in a line facing the class with their letters hidden. Ask the class how likely they think it is that when the three letters are shown that the three letters will make a word. Then get the students one by one from left to right reveal their letters.
  7. Get students to generate three letter "words" by randomly selecting three letterswithout replacementfrom the five letters you used (they could work in groups with their own set of five cards). This will require students to decide if a word is real or not. If you want to help students spot correct words, you could do a round of "Bogggle" and get the class to create as many valid three letter words as possible from the five letters without repeating letters. Depending on previous learning, you may need to discuss the concept of probability estimates (AKA experimental probability), before getting students to generate 20 "words" (or more if you like!), counting how many of these "words" were real, and determining an estimate for the probability.
  8. Discuss how a simulation could be set up using a computer to run thousands of trials to check randomly created words from the five letters against a list of three letter words that are "real" to determine a closer estimate of the modelprobability (AKA theoretical probability). This process of checking words against a list of "true words"could be compared to processes around checking whether an emailaddresssubmitted to an online signup form is "real" or not. We need keep linking what we do in the classroom with the real world :-)
  9. You could explore the model probability by considering the total number of "words" that could be created by randomly selecting three letters from the five without replacement (e.g. 5 x 4 x 3 = 60) and the total number of real words found by systematically trying out all permutations or by using aScrabble tool like this one(e.g. for my five letters it's elevenreal words).
  10. You could finish by looking at the "Infinite Monkey Theorem". This will require a bit more of a theoretical focusand understanding ofcomplementary events and the usefulness of finding P(X = 0) when you need to find P(X 1). This kind of thinking can be referred to whenever a new animal is found to be awesome at predicting the results of sports games e.g.Paul the Octopus,Richie McCow
Want to read more? Kaplan et al. (2014) Exploitinglexical ambiguity to help students understand the meaning of random Resources TWIG resources for infinite monkey theorem

item.title: Exploring statistical measures by estimating the ages of famous people
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: This lesson focuses on developing student understanding of statistical measures. It is a re-working of a workshop I offered for the NZAMT 2009 conference. This lesson is awesome because students drive the development of a measure for determining the best age estimator. I was introduced to the activity when I was at teachers' college, and have used it in my teaching pretty much every year since then in some way or another. I adapted it to focus on creating a variety of measures (not just the standard deviation) during some early work on the SOLO taxonomy, as a way of demonstrating progressions in thinking. item.title: Probability teaching ideas using simulation
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This post provides some teaching examples for using an online probability simulation tool. It's asupplement to theworkshop I offered for the NZAMT 2015 conference. Probability simulation tool I recently developed a verybasic online probability simulation tool .I wanted a simulation tool that would run online without using applets or flash (tablet compatible). I also wanted tobeable to animate repeated simulations in a loop - in the past to get this effect, I had to either make animated GIFs or set up slides in Powerpoint to transition automatically. I did a quick search for online simulation tools and couldn't find what I wanted so I adapted some code I had written previously to get what I wanted. An example of an animated looped simulation fromthe probability simulation tool It's very much designed "fit for a specific purpose" (more about that in the part 2) so I know it has lots of limitations :-) But what I like about the feature being demonstrated above is that it will keep running automatically, freeing me up to ask the students questions about what they are seeing and why they are seeing this. Small samples - lots of variation One of the activities I presented in the workshop involved teachers trying to work out who my siblings were based on photos. I presented five sets of four photos. Within each set, one photo was of one of my siblings, the rest were photos of other non-related people. In the workshop there around 30 teachers present. The basic idea (with lots of assumptions) is that distribution for the number of correct selections IF teachers were guessing can be modelled by a binomial distribution with n = 5 and p = 0.25. After "marking" the teachers selections of my siblings, I created a dot plot of the 30 individual results. One of the questions put to the teachers at the workshop was "Do these results look like what we'd see if each of you was guessing which person was my sibling?"' To build up a simulated distribution based on guessing, each teacher then usedfive different hands-on simulations to make new sibling selections for each set of photos(see the resources link at the end of this post). I then created another dot plot from these simulated selections and asked teachers to compare the features of the two plots e.g. centre, spread, shape, unusual. For this workshop, the two distributions actually came out to look pretty similar.But this won't necessary happen. To demonstrate the amount of variation between repeated simulations (of 30 students guessing across five sets of possible siblings), I set up the probability simulation toolwith the options shown in the screen grab below: So that the axis does not resize for each simulation, I fixed the axis between 0 and 5. To stop the dots from automatically resizing, I fixed the dot size to the smallest option. I then pressed"Start animation" and let the simulations run over and over again. This gives the following animation: This animation couldthenbe used to ask questions like:
  • "What would be an unlikely number of correct siblings if someone was guessing?"
  • "How many correct siblings would you expect to see if someone was guessing - between where and where?"
  • "What looks similar for each animation?"- "What looks different?"
  • "What variation are we seeing?" - "Why are we seeing it?"
  • "What does one dot on the graph represent?"
  • "How is the simulated data being generated?"
Want to read/see more? Wild, C. Animations of sampling variation Wild, C. VIT - Visual inference tools NZ Senior secondary guide - Lateness: Choice or chance Resources Workshop materials - stimulating simulations NZAMT 2015 Online probability simulation tool

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: Probability teaching ideas using probsim - part 1 ~ #statisticsisawesome

item.title: How long does it take a student to submit a swear word into a text analysis tool?
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: Update on the predictive text challenge I haven't heard anything from anyone with any problems, and there seems to be a bit of traffic to the challenge page, so hopefully this is going well. I'll allow checking of the first list of reserved words tomorrow. Students should put in what they predict the readability score will be for each word. These predicted scores will be checked against the actual readability scores and students will be given an overall result e.g. 85%.Oh, and just because you're a teacher too you'll get this idea for an investigative question/problem....... How long does it take a student to submit a swear word into a text analysis tool? Related "reading themed" statistical investigation ideas Check outhttp://josephrocca.com/randomsentence/where you can generate "random" sentences from books that are no longer under U.S.A. copyright restrictions - so books generally published before the early 20th century. You could compare the process for random sampling sentences from digital books to processes for random sampling sentences from physical books (so much here with different sampling methods). You could give students an actual physical book and challenge them to estimate the total word count (check using the digital version!), or get students to devise a way to compare the "readability" of two books, or....? So what was so surprising? Recap: I got 10 dominoes from a supermarket recently and was surprised to find that all 10 were different (there are 50 different dominoes to collect). Ok, so on the face of it this may look like a familiar (and not super awesome) starter. Collecting cereal cards, ice block sticks, seed packets........ But I was surprised to see this because I was thinking that a random process like this would mean I should expect to see at least one double up e.g. like seeing runs of heads when you flip a coin. When I thought about it more, I realised I wasn't taking into account there were 50 dominoes - this makes a difference. More about SOLO SOLO stands for the Structure of the Observed Learning Outcomes. It's a model/taxonomy for defining different levels of understanding or thinking and was developed by J. Biggs and K. Collis in 1982. I've been using SOLO in my teaching of statistics since around 2006 and think it's awesome. It fits so well with building conceptual understandings of statistics rather than just procedural ones. I use SOLO in (at least) two ways: (1) to structure good questions for students to use when working with data, questions to make them think at different levels and (2) to plan my teaching of a topic e.g. what are the key ideas (not skills)? The prices increased from Jan to Feb and then decreased from Mar to May and then increased again..... I think I like this answer on Quora re how to explain over-fitting of models.Some of the language is a bit off - I think if you swap the word "hypothesis" for "model" and remove "experiments" and replace with "observations" it reads better. But I like the idea of how to explain to students that a model is not about getting a perfect fit to the observed data and that simpler can be better (e.g. go for the minimum number of trend lines as possible that tell the general story of what is happening......).

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: How long does it take for a student to submit a swear word..... ~ #statisticsisawesome

item.title: Writing report comments ..... using a little bit of statistics :-)
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: This is a post about my new tool to help write report comments for statistics (and mathematics) students. You can find it under the new "Tools" menu, but you might want to read the stuff below first to find out how it works :-) A very brief history of my approach to writing report comments.... A good friend of mine (also a teacher) once commented that I spent more time thinking and creating tools to write report comments than the actual time it would take to just write them by hand.I did write my report comments "by hand" for the first couple of years of teaching, but then I realised that, while every student is different, I wasn't necessarily using completely different comments about each student. There was a structure to what I was writing and some key things I was commenting on regarding what the student was doing (or not doing) in terms of their learning. So a started developingtools to help me (and others) write report comments. Developing the new reporting writing tool... My goal with this new version of the report writing tool was to make the process more natural and for comments to be "suggested" in the writing process (rather than using drop-down boxes), similar to how Google suggests search terms for you as you type. For this suggestion process to work well, I had to analyse all the comments I had used before to identify words that were useful at identifying comments and words that were not. For example, I found that most words less than four letters long were not that useful at selecting useful comments, and words like "have", "take" etc. also were not useful at presenting reasonable options for comments. I ran some of my previously written comments through some text analysis tools to check out aspects such as readability and word length. [caption id="attachment_228" align="alignnone" width="826"] Some basic analysis - distribution of word lengths[/caption] Want to see it in action? I've made this video to explain how to use the tool because I think it's easier this way :-) Or just try it out for yourself here

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: My new report comment writing tool ..... using a little bit of statistics :-) ~ #statisticsisawesome

item.title: New tool for statistics students - the experiment lab!
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded:
This post is about a new tool that I've developed that allows students to play and create different versions of an online game. The context - online game design (or...... How can we design an app to make us millions?) I've embedded the online game within this post so you can have a go but you would send students towww.mathstatic.co.nz/experiment-laborwww.mathstatic.co.nz/experiment-lab/alphabet-challengeto play the game etc. The basic idea behind developing these games is that you need to award points somehow, you need different levels of difficulty for the game and you need a way for the game to end ....... oh and you need to make it addictive! For this particular game, there is no points system and no way to move players up through levels. This (hopefully) gives a rich context to explore lots of statistics ideas :-) When thinking about how to use the game and the experiment lab in teaching statistics, a really important teacher understanding is that the data created from playing the game exists initially within an "experimenting world", not a "sampling world". So, unless you are going to use actual random samples from defined populations (e.g. a random sample of students from your school), then this game/data should not be used directly for teaching sample-to-population inference or for exploring sampling variation. But you can definitely explore other sources of variation with this game, as well as important ideas around study design e.g. defining and measuring variables, carrying out an experiment etc.Toget the "ball rolling" I'll start with a few ideas, which are in no particular order and written as independent lessons/activities ............ How do you measure performance in the game? The original version of the game only records the time to complete the game, so you could base your teaching around getting students to define or create other measures of performance. In the experiment lab, they can choose to measure other aspects of performance. Other measures could also be developed and measured by students e.g. how "stressed" a player felt during the game, whether they "rage quit" or not. If you do come up with other measures that you would like to add to the game, let me know and I'll try to include them. Here's how I came up with the performance measures in the experiment lab....... Originally I started with the time in seconds to "connect the dots" as the performance measure. I realised quickly that a second is actually quite a long time and that this was not accurate enough. Playing the game initially with the time measured to the nearest second could be used to do some teaching around measurement error e.g. if two players both get 4 seconds as the time recorded for completing the game, does this mean they both finished at exactly the same time? In the experiment lab, students have the option to round the time measurements to 0, 1, 2, or 3 decimal places. As I played with different words I noticed that it took me longer to start the game when there were more letters to have search through to find the letter I needed, so I added a measure for how long it takes for the first click.I noticed as I was playing the game that often I missed the dot when trying to click it, so added the number of clicks as a measure. I also wanted to compare the number clicks to the number of letters to see how many times I missed, so I added the number of letters as a measure. I was also interested in whether some games were easier/harder to play because the dots started/stayed closer together (the game randomly decides where to place the dots at the beginning of the game, more about this later....), so I added a measure for the distance between each click when a dot was hit (measured in pixels). I then noticed that in games when I was really struggling I was moving the mouse a lot around as I tried to "track" the dots, so I added a measure for the distance the mouse is moved during the game (measured in pixels). In terms of the accuracy of the times recorded, there will be a very slight delay between the actual click and the time recorded, while the code behind the game does its calculations. I can't notice the delay when I play, but it could be that for different devices the delay is longer (or shorter). The game plays on the "client side" so there is no need to consider internet speed or server load. Here's another version of the game that shows you all the current performance measures and with the time rounded to two decimal places - have a go! Can you get betterat the game? The original version of the game will give each student a starting word for the game, randomly selected from a list of approved words. Get the students to play the game once and to write down the time. Then get them to play the game again with the same word and compare this time to their first time. Depending on the settings you have used, you might need to change the rounding of the time measurement for students to be able to see a difference (or incorporate this as part of the teaching - the need to measure time more accurately than seconds). Get the students to keep playing the game with the same word so they can notice different kinds of variation: variation in their own times, potential decrease of times with practice, variation in how the game positions the letters of the word and how the letters move during the game. Then get the students to try out another word (click new word), again repeating the game with this new word multiple times.For example, here are my times for repeating the same word four times for four different words, represented on a line graph: A reason why the "practice effect" is not very strong when playing this game is because even with the same word, each game is different because the starting positions and angles for each letter differ (assigned using a random process). I've played the game many times, and generally my time decreases between the first and second attempts of the same word for shorter words, but then the time goes back up again for subsequent attempts.I haven't noticed much of a difference for the longer words for the times to complete the game.The weak/non-existent practice effect for longer words is helpful for exploring paired comparison experimental designs. Most games involve randomness in the game design, so the next question could be whether the game is fair if each game is different? Does the scoring system (if it existed) need to take into account how the letters were placed at the start of the game? Or does it all just balance out? How can you make different levels of the game? In the experiment lab, there are lots of ways to modify the game. If you think about a simple "comparison of two independent groups" design, then students can learn as much from two versions of the game that give "different" results than two versions that give "similar" results. I've played the game many times during its development and there are just so many comparisons to be explored, but here are a few ideas. Of course, everything else for the game would be kept the same (same word, same dot size, speed, same instructions etc.) except for the treatment described below:
  • Word displayed in order vs reverse order
  • No movement vs slow movement
  • Bright red coloured background vs light grey coloured background
  • One word vs another word
Some of these comparisons are also related to what you are measuring for the performance e.g. I wouldn't expect to see much of a difference between the time to first click for words displayed in order vs reverse order. This is a good thing, as students should be justifying their selection of variables :-) Not all words will necessary suit the type of experiment they want to conduct, which they should learn from trying out the experiment on themselves first. It is also possible to create very different versions of the games, but the player needs to be taken into account. For example, using small dots with the highest speed will lead to rage quit! [well, if there was a quit button - the stop button is all that is on offer!] We want the game to be addictive - challenging enough for players to keep interested but not so difficult that they just give up. How can you award points for playing the game? You could think about awarding points for the game in terms of rewarding good playing (skill) and punishing bad playing (no skill). This links to the earlier question about how to measure performance. To demonstrate bad playing, you could set up a version of the game so that the dots are not visible (using the same colour of the dots as the background colour and letter colour), so students have to guess where to click to select the correct dot. Give it a go below: Did you give up? It took me 84 clicks :-) Clearly skill is involved when you play the game and "random" clicking is probably not going to help you click the correct dot faster. So it could be that the points are initially awarded based on the time to complete the game, but points are then taken off for extra clicks. To award points based on the time to complete the game needs a way to "baseline" the game to take into account different words. So the students will need to explore relationships between the performance measures e.g. the number of letters of the word vs the time to complete the activity. Also, if two performance measures appear to have a relationship, than it might not make sense to use both variables to determine points (e.g. time to first click and time to complete the game). Each player brings their own level of skill and practice with the game, but can we use two of the performance measures to find out more about how people play the game? I think there are a lot of good reasons to explore the relationships between the performance measures..... More about the game..... This is the first stageof an online game I'm developing, built off code from this websitewith my own additions and improvements. There are lots of similar games out there involving balls - here are just a couple:
  • Hit bricks with a ball game(top left hand corner - click the button that says run code)
  • Catch a ball game
  • Chain reaction game
If you (or your students) are interested in the design of the game itself, just look at the page source of this page to see the code. There is a fair bit of logic and mathematics involved (e.g. trigonometry, co-ordinate geometry, measurement).I've set the words used for the game to a fixed "approved" list so students can't create games with dodgy words, even if they try to hack the link used to access a different version of the game :-) Resources Experiment lab for students on mathstatic.co.nz Alphabet challenge on mathstatic.co.nz Link to just the game with default settings

wp:postmeta.wp:meta_value: New tool for statistics students - the experiment lab! ~ #statisticsisawesome

item.title: Predicting gender from dating profiles
item.dc:creator: anna
item.content:encoded: This post features a quiz asking you topredict the gender of someone based on what they write about themselves on a dating website. How does the quiz work? You will be given 20 different "About me" descriptions taken from public profiles displayed on a dating website. For each description, you will need to select whether you think this description is from a male or female profile. Note:Your choices will be recorded and this data may be used for a future post. No personal information about you will be recorded. Get started! [WpProQuiz 1]
